We declined the offer of for-profit violence this time. They'll just have to find someone else to pay them for their dirty work.
I just hope that someone doesn't decide to send these guys against us.

Gustav came by today to let us know that we've been such good customers he's willing to give us exclusive access to his 'special' inventory.
Hopefully this new stuff is worth it, and [doesn't smell like it was pulled out of a dumpster|actually works|isn't covered in mold] for a change.

Gustav's obviously been doing well for himself. His caravan [*looks like it has a new paint job|has been plated in chrome|is barely able to move it's so heavily loaded with goods] and his new bodyguards [*are all armed with the best refurbished weapons|look like the sort that eat broken glass and floss with barbed wire|look like they've had actual military training].
When we asked him about it he told us that this was thanks to all the business we'd given him, and to show his appreciation, he was going to give us access to his 'executive' goods.

Gustav and his [brother Boris|sister Vera] stopped by to give us a message. They've been doing so well (thanks to all the business we've been giving them) that they've been able to stock up with a bunch of special gear. They're giving us first crack at it too.
Maybe this means I'll finally be able to get that [*pony|Zombie Killer 3000|air rifle] I always wanted.

Gustav travels with some odd people these days. A man with an impressive handlebar mustache came riding over from their camp on one of those old-timey pennyfarthing bikes, pulling a brightly painted cartload of hand-hammered wooden spikes with a sign that read "Artisinal Zombie Traps".
"I deal only in experiences," he said. "Offer me something novel, and I will trade you my beautiful hand-crafted traps."

The man was clearly offended.
"I can think of nothing so mundane as what you have offered. I require nourishment for my soul, no mere bodily sustenance. I must take my business elsewhere."
He got back on his goofy bike and rode off.

"Actually, not all that novel an experience at all." the man sniffed and rubbed his sore cheek. "Nobody appreciates true craftsmanship anymore."
He got back on his goofy bike and rode wobbily away.
He also noticed we knew how to make our own traps, and shared his research on Advanced Traps design.

Gustav brought over his sister Vera today. He's spent the past hour trying to convince us that we should pay for the privilege of hearing her play her antique violin.
I'm not sure anyone's playing is worth 10 food, but heaven knows we could do with some new entertainment. If we have to sit through another night of [Name's] [orchestrated belching|flatulent pyrotechnics|recitations of old cartoon theme songs] I'm going to put someone's eye out.

A woman named Vera stopped by the fort today carrying an old violin case. She claims to be Gustav's sister. Given that she's asking for 10 food just to hear her play, I'm guessing the drive for business runs in the family.
I don't know if she knows [anything written in the past century|any of my favorite old video game themes|anything by Rupert Lally or Espen J. Jörgensen] but at this point, any music would probably raise our spirits.
Pay to hear her play (10 food)

Vera's music was nothing short of amazing. Her folk ballads from the old country brought people to tears, and she could pick up modern tunes from just a few hummed bars.
We all went to bed far more relaxed than we've felt in weeks.

It was a concert I'll never forget. Vera's playing was so stunningly beautiful, I completely forgot the world around me and lost myself in her music for a few hours. I asked her how she learned to play that well, but she just shrugged and showed me her violin.
_"Iz antique Stradivari,"_ she said, _"price two million dollars, once. Now, iz mine."_

We told Vera we couldn't pay and she simply shrugged and turned her back without saying another word.
It's no big deal. I mean, it's not like on my death bed I'll be wondering if I just missed a live performance from an unparalleled virtuoso...

Gustav's been leering at [FormalName] during the last few visits and it looks like things have finally come to a head.
He's asked if we'd be willing to part with [him] in return for a flame thrower he scavenged from a military base, and 100 fuel to run it. Gustav thinks [Name] would be a wonderful addition to his 'Love Caravan'.
[Name] doesn't want to go, but I think I could convince [him] it's in everybody's best interest and is probably safer than sticking with us.

Gustav has a bad habit of looking at our women the same way he looks at trade goods.
[FormalName] seems to have caught his eye this time, and Gustav is offering offer to... I guess buy [him] from us. He's offering a flame thrower and 100 fuel to run it, if we're willing to let [Name] join Gustav's love caravan.
[Name] is unhappy, but I think I can convince [him]. Gustav does feed his ladies regular meals, and says he _"never losink girl to zombie"_.

I laid it out to [Name]: in Gustav's caravan [he]'ll never go hungry, do guard duty or get [his] hands dirty. Plus [he]'ll be doing a great service to us.
[Name] didn't cry. [He] just rammed [his] steel-toed boot smartly in my kneecap, spat at Gustav, grabbed a bag of our trade goods and stormed out of the fort alone.
Gustav just shrugged. _"I guess iz not meant to be with that firey one. I will give you gun for tryink, but only half fuel for no girl."_
[Name] was totally relieved. I think [he] actually thought I was going to say yes for a minute there. Would never have happened. Well... probably not.

I flipped out at Gustav. I told him if he so much as _considered_ treating our people like property to be bought and sold again, he'd find his balls nailed to the front gate as a warning message to anyone else.
He took the hint and left in short order, unconsciously keeping a hand over his crotch.
I doubt he'll want to deal with us for awhile, but it sure made me feel better. And most of our people are in higher spirits since seeing the spectacle, especially [Name].

This came at just the right time. We've been low on food and struggling to keep people fed. Then suddenly [faction] show up with like a whole crate of [mixed nuts|juiceboxes|dried ravioli]. I don't know where they found it, but I guess they must really like us or something. Good thing!
Turns out [faction] has more food than they know what to do with. They decided to share the bounty with us rather than let any of it spoil. It couldn't have come at a better time.

We found a wheelbarrow full of [cabbages|lettuce] outside the gate with a note:
Hope these heads give you the strength to keep yours. - [faction]

[Faction] must have noticed how skinny we've all gotten lately, because they came by to offer us a bunch of free food. I suspect these are just the leftovers from a big party they threw last night, but I'm not going to say anything. Any food is good food at this point.

[Name] just found something odd. [He] was taking some quiet time in our [square], [*playing jacks with an old tennis ball and some rusty nails|reading a weathered newspaper of days gone by], when [he] stumbled on some hidden steps covered by debris.
The steps lead underground to a massive vault-like door. We're not sure what's down there, but [Name] thinks [he] heard scratching from other side. Do we want to open it to see what's inside, or just seal it up so no one accidentally lets out whatever's in there?

[Name] got into a bit of an accident today. [He] found a [*huge SUV|cruiser motorbike|rusted jeep] that still had some gas left in the tank and decided to take it for a joyride. [His] crash in the [square] was fairly spectacular. I'm still amazed [he] was able to walk away from it. The vehicle wasn't so lucky.
The weird thing is the crash revealed this bricked up door we hadn't seen before. While I'd like to see what's behind it, I could've sworn I heard something moving on the other side. Should we open it, or seal it back up?

[Name] was poking around our [square] to see if we missed anything in our initial scavenging sweep when [he] found an old-fashioned trap door that doesn't look like it's been touched in ages.
We've got no idea where it leads, but the few legible words scrawled on it ("[Danger... Man Eating...|Warning... Lethal Contaminants...|Abandon all hope... enter here...|Trespassers... Shot...]") don't inspire confidence. Do we want to investigate or seal the thing up?

The instant we cracked open the door, a hand that was more bone than flesh shot out and tried to grab [Name] by the collar. It was all we could to get everyone out of there and barricade off the area as the undead came pouring out of the hole.
Now we've got a small horde of zed trapped in the middle of our fort and nothing to show for it. Just another Tuesday I guess.

The door led, somewhat anti-climatically, to a musty old store room. Aside from a few cockroaches, it didn't look like anyone had been down there in months, if not years.
What we did find were crates of canned goods, medical supplies and ammo. We're going to be celebrating tonight! [Anchovies|SPAM|Canned spaghetti] for all!

"Discretion is the better part of valor" as they say. I'm not actually sure how true that statement is, but the people who say it are generally the ones who survive, and that's what's important.
We spent a couple hours piling rocks and concrete in front of it, just in case. No one is going to be opening that door any time soon.

I'm not sure what to do with [FormalName]. I found [him] shoving the remains of some old [*hot rod|muscle car|gas guzzler] through the front gate this morning. Seems the thing caught [his] eye and [he]'s determined to try to get it going again.
I suppose it could be a good learning experience for [him]. Should we give [him] time off to try to get it working? Or ask [him] to take the piece of junk apart and see what makes it tick? Maybe get some useful scrap out of it at least.

Everyone remembers their first love. Their [*curves|strength|fiery passion]. How [*they lit up the night sky|they moved you]. The way they could [*transport half-a-ton of construction equipment|ford a foot-deep stream without getting a speck of rust on their cab|grip tight to the road, even in the iciest of conditions]...
Looks like [FormalName] has found [himself] one such love. An [*El Camino|old SUV] that looks like it's seen better days. I don't know if [he]'ll be able to get the thing working, but [he] might learn a thing or two if [he] takes it apart.

I never took [FormalName] for a car person, but [he]'s had [his] head stuffed into the hood of an old [*Ferrari|Lotus|Tesla] for a couple of days now.
The thing was hot stuff back in the day, but I don't know how much use it'll be now with the roads so full of zed. That's assuming [he] can even get the thing working. Maybe we should just get [him] to take it apart for scrap.

[Name] got it to run, once, for about two blocks before [*the front axle cracked right in two|engine burst into flames|gas tank fell out of the bottom of the car], taking the rest of the car with it. Too bad we didn't have a proper workshop for [him] to use.
On the bright side [he] had a great time working on it. That's what really matters.
I can't believe [Name] actually got that hunk of junk running. It made it easier that we had a proper workshop for [him] to use I suppose. [He]'s happy as a clam now in [his] new car.

[Name] was sad to pull [his] beauty to pieces, but [he] really got in to the experience, learning as much as [he] could about every piece [he] dismantled.
[He] even [*started to write a book about the experience|put together a presentation describing the process]. We may just have a scholar on our hands here.
Cassandra hugged me. "Congratulations again on having a majority of Chosen Ones followers." she said. "This grants you Clear Aura status among us... and access to many of our secrets."
Does this mean you'll tell us where the lab is?

Cassandra laughed. "Please tell me you didn't convert half of your people to my religion just so I'd tell you where that lab was."
When I didn't say anything, her smile got a little thinner. "The facility is under one of our [squares]. If you meet me there, I'll show you the way inside."
Mission available to Enter the Lab

[Name2] was out [missioning] with [Name] when [he2] caught movement out of the corner of [his2] eye.
Some kind of figure wearing a black mask... [he2] thought it was a zombie at first, but it didn't move like a zombie. And even less zombielike was the way it brandished that knife as it ran at [Name].

[Name] was out [missioning] when a figure in a black mask ran at [him] from the shadows.
It flew past [him] and slashed at [his] ankle as it went, just about severing [his] Achilles tendon. [Name] hopped around on one foot but stayed upright, and gave the attacker a whooping punch in the head when it came in for a second swipe. It had enough and retreated down an alley.
[Name's] hurt, but alive. If this was an assassination or kidnapping attempt, we better make sure not to send [him] anywhere alone.

[Name2] pushed [Name] down and turned to grapple with the mysterious attack ninja, but it leaped over both of them and just kept running. I guess without the element of surprise, it gave up. Good thing [Name2] was there!
If this was an assassination or kidnapping attempt on [Name], we better make sure not to send [him] anywhere alone.

[Name2] jumped out of the way. The ninja creature flew past [Name] and slashed at [his] ankle as it went, just about severing [his] Achilles tendon.
[Name] hopped around on one foot but stayed upright, and gave the attacker a whopping punch in the head when it came in for a second swipe. It had enough, and retreated down an alley.
[Name] is hurt, but alive. If this was an assassination or kidnapping attempt, we better make sure not to send [him] anywhere alone.

[Name2] pushed [Name] down and turned to grapple with the mysterious attack ninja, but it leaped over both of them and just kept running. I guess without the element of surprise, it gave up. [Name2] chased it for several blocks but eventually lost it around a corner. There one second... gone the next.
If this was some kind of assassination or kidnapping attempt on [Name], we better make sure not to send [him] anywhere alone.

[Name] and [Name2] were [missioning] together at [a] [square] when there was a second attempt on [Name's] life.
A crossbow bolt embedded itself with a _twonk_ in the ground beside [his] feet.
[Name2] reacted quickly...

[Name] was out at [a] {1} when there was a second attempt on [his] life. This time crossbow bolts rained down on [him] from above. One embedded itself in [his] calf before [he] escaped down an alley.
[Name] didn't stop running until [he] made it back to the fort, the bolt wobbling in [his] leg the whole way. [He]'s going to need a few days to recuperate from this one.
We really should have known better than to send [him] out there alone...

[Name2] grabbed [Name] and herded [him] to safety in a doorway. [Name] continued through the building and left from another exit while [Name2] made a bunch of noise to keep the attacker's attention.
It was a good plan and it worked: they both made it back to the fort unharmed.

[Name2] ran for a doorway, leaving [Name] alone in the street. Crossbow bolts rained down on [him] from above, and one embedded itself in [his] calf before [he] escaped down an alley.
[Name] didn't stop running until [he] made it back to the fort, the bolt wobbling in [his] leg the whole way. [He]'s going to need a few days to recuperate from this one.
[He]'s also lucky the attacker wasn't a better shot.

[Name2] grabbed [Name] and herded [him] to safety in a doorway. Then [he2] had [Name] continue through the building and leave from another exit while [Name2] chased down the attacker.
It was that damn ninja again, up on the roof of a nearby building. But by the time [Name2] found a way up there, it was gone.
At least they both made it back to the fort unharmed!

[FormalName] was alone out there when they finally got [him]. We're not sure what happened exactly, but we know [he] didn't go down without a fight: [his] body was so covered in knife cuts that we couldn't even tell which one had killed [him].
Whether it was an assassination or a botched kidnapping, [Name] is dead. We're sorry we sent [him] out there to [his] fate alone.

Yet another attack on [Name] while [he] was out [missioning]. This is starting to get old. It's not clear if this ninja guy is actually trying to capture [him], or is just a very inept assassin.
[Name2] was on the lookout for danger and saw the attack coming first. It started with a smoke bomb...

[Name] can't even take a crap these days without some masked ninja trying to incapacitate [him].
[He] was out [missioning] with [Name2] when a cloud of smoke enveloped them both...

[FormalName2] knew [he2] was on bodyguard duty when we assigned [him2] with [Name]. It was only a question of when [he2]'d have to risk [his2] life for the [guy].
They weren't even halfway out to the [square] when the first smoke grenade landed at their feet...

[Name2] flailed about at the smoke. If [he2] can't see, the ninja can't see either.
A knife flashed through the mists and cut deeply into [his2] arm. Somehow [he2] managed to grapple the attacker and they wrestled blindly through the smoke... But when the smoke cleared the ninja was gone. [Name2] and [Name] were grappling each other.
[Name's] injured, but at least they both survived the attack.

[Name2] fled the smoke cloud with tears streaming from [his2] eyes. [He2] listened as [Name] wrestled the attacker alone.
[Name] failed.
Whether it was an assassination or a botched kidnapping, [FormalName] was killed in the attack. We're sorry we couldn't keep [him] safe.

[Name2] flailed about at the smoke. Somehow [he2] managed to grapple the attacker, but it slipped away and ran off down the street.
[Name2] followed right on its heels. A little too close; [he2] rounded a corner and found [himself2] skewered on the ninja's long knife.
It's a miracle the stab wound didn't kill [him2], but there's a reason we picked [Name2] for bodyguard duty. [He2]'s tough. [He2]'ll recover. And [Name] is safe.

[Name2] flailed about at the smoke. Somehow [he2] managed to grapple the attacker and get the knife out of its grip.
When the smoke cleared they removed its mask: it was an older woman with a hideous scar across her face that had taken her nose with it.
They asked her name, who does she work for, and why try to kill [Name], but she said nothing. She waited for the right moment then, without hesitation, wriggled free, grabbed the knife, and slit her own throat.

We found Cassandra's private documents during our last attack on the The Church of the Chosen Ones. They included notes for an upcoming sermon on the promotion of positive energy in bodily fluids (gross), a list of church members ranked by "trustworthiness" and "gullibility", and a set of vaguely worded status updates on some sort of research project. It mentioned [a] {1}; I suspect we might find the lab we're looking for there.
Who knows what's still going on in there. We better bring some muscle, and maybe an engineer or two.
Mission available to Enter the Lab

Cassandra brought a contingent of Chosen Ones followers to greet us at our fort. We've met her before in branches in other cities, but this time we're on her home turf. [CityName] is the Church's headquarters and spiritual center. They've been here long enough to spread out and get comfortable.
If she saw us as a threat, Cassandra hid it well. She greeted me with a warm hug.

Cassandra closed her eyes to compose herself first.
"They say man is an endangered species."
"We say: man has evolved. The Chosen Ones are the new rulers of earth; the next species in the evolution of humanity from bacteria to monkeys to gods."
"When you finally clear your aura of all blemishes, you will all know this to be true. You will join them."

"An underground biology lab?" she asked doubtfully. "You must have the wrong city. There's nothing like that in [CityName]. I'm sure we'd know about it if there was."
I tried to press her but she changed the subject. "Would you like to buy one of our books? These are [CityName] bestsellers you know. And not just because our members are all required to own five copies each."

Cassandra rose up to her full height - she's an impressively tall woman - and glared down at me.
"I'm horrified that you would even suggest my people would do something like that. Whoever this [FormalName] is, I've never even met [him]."
She gathered her people and left without another word.
Uh... did I tell her [his] last name? Maybe I did? But I don't think so...

The Church of the Chosen Ones set up a party for us with a banner reading "Welcome, Clear Auras!"
Half of our survivors have adopted their religion, and as a group we've attended enough sessions and bought enough of their books to gain access to their most secret of secrets.
The lab! Cassandra offered to show us around if we meet her there at the [square].
Mission available to Enter the Lab

[FormalName] is such a sweetie, [he] even shares [his] food with the dogs. I'm talking good quality real people food; a box of sugared dates [he] found in [his] apartment. [He] figured someone must have left it as a gift but no... not so lucky.
The poor dog {1} ate a couple dates from [Name's] hand. Then the old boy keeled right over dead, just as [Name] was about to pop one in [his] mouth.
Poisoned dates?? Yes, we tested them. But who would do this? One of our own?

It must have been one of our own, and that's something we absolutely can't have. Forget privacy, forget rights. We raided people's homes and searched their possessions until we found the evidence.
[FormalName2] had another box of dates and a bottle of rat poison in [his2] kitchen. We confronted [him2] and sure enough [he2] ran. Up on the wall, [he2] answered the crowd's shouts of "why did you do it?" with a swan dive into the zombies on the other side.

This isn't worth upsetting everybody over. Nobody was hurt. Well, a dog died, which is tragic but... but that's kind of what they're for now.
Okay [Name], from now on, we're going to assign you an official canine taster, okay? Like royalty. And please don't eat anything else if you don't know where it came from.

The entrance looked like a nondescript underground parking lot, lit by dim orange emergency lights. So we were surprised that the sliding doors at the far end still worked, and even more surprised to find a busy, well lit laboratory on the other side of them.
A rabbit in a labcoat scurried past [us]. Correction: a woman wearing a labcoat and a plastic rabbit mask scurried past. [We] followed her to the "offices" wing, trying not to stare too long at the other animal-faced scientists.
In the director's office, [we] met a familiar face...

[We] met Cassandra at the entrance and [she] led us down through the dark tunnel. We were surprised to emerge into a modern, working, well-lit laboratory. Staffed by animals... or at least people wearing animal masks.
She paused outside the director's office and spoke quickly in a hushed voice. "This project was initiated by his holiness the Living Osiris. Since he came to us, we have been but instruments to his greatness. I must leave you now but please, don't anger him..."

"Don't answer that partner." Jesse appeared like a ghost behind [us]. As he drew his pistols, Clark hit a button on his desk and the wall beside him slid open to the sound of sirens. He dove through it and it closed again behind him.
After a startled moment, we heard his voice over the PA system:
"Hahaha, good try, but I'm behind three feet of solid steel and I've got all the research with me. You shouldn't have teamed up with the Rotten. They're useless. No imagination. They want to be _cured_ for god's sake! Who wants to be human again? Not me!"

"I can't hear you." Clark voice echoed over the PA. "But you're probably whining about how great it is to be alive. You're wrong! Once I get this cure synthesized, I'll make an army of undead warriors. Super strong and impervious to pain, but I'll stop the disease before they forget how to use weapons or obey commands. Then I'll rule the world hahahaha ha!"
Zombies came rushing into the hall outside, clumsily wielding baseball bats and metal pipes.
"Oh, finally, here comes security. Get 'em boys!"

We made it out of that lab ahead of Clark's semi-intelligent security force, but only because they stopped to snack on a bird-faced researcher.
"That didn't go so well, did it?" said Jesse. "I guess there's just no dialogin' with some folks. We'll just have to blow him outta there."
I was about to say that _Jesse_ was the one who drew his gun and ruined our dialog, but he's right: explosives. We'll bring a heap of them down here and blow the door off that vault. Just as soon as we deal with all these zombies...
Mission available to Blow up Lab

Whoa, is that... is that _Kevin Clark_? The McManager? Seriously?
He recognized [us] too. "The meddlers! Who let you in here?" he jumped up from his desk. "I suppose you're here to try to stop me, but hear me out first!"
"The researchers here, they were close to a cure. They had a recipe and were trying to synthesize it when something went wrong. There were bodies everywhere when I found this place. Real mess. Took my new lackies a month to clean it all up."

He interrupted me. "They call me Osiris. I think the animal masks are some Egyptian thing too. Their screwy cult is such nonsense... but they've been useful. It's remarkable what people will do in the name of faith."
"So, synthesizing this cure... the thing is, we need brain tissue from someone immune to the disease. [FormalName's] immune and he knows it, that escaping bastard. So here's the deal: you bring me [Name], and we can share the cure when I make it."

I woke early this morning to frantic banging on our gates. "Lemme in! They're gonna drag me back down there I can't go back to that lab zombie poking me with needles it tried to cut me up with a knife I can't go back lemme in lemme in!"
The man was delirious and bleeding, but unarmed. We tentatively opened the door and he barged in huffing. "Oh thank you good people they had me strapped to a table for days and they did something to my head I feel so woozy I hate confinement some people can handle it but I can't handle closed spaces..."

"Well... it was dark and I was drugged up and confused. I don't remember much. After I escaped I slept in [a] {1} nearby... then I headed straight down the road for the woods; they were like... {2} blocks away I think. I passed [a] {3} on the way."
"Listen, I'm sure I could find the entrance if I saw it again. But you've got to let me stay with you. You've got to protect me from those maniacs."
We agreed. We can send Bill to scout any building for that hidden lab entrance.
Offer him a big meal (2 food)

"Ouch! Whyddya do that?" The man rubbed his face and shook his head a little. "I was kind of hysterical eh? Guess the drugs they gave me haven't worn off yet. I'll try to toughen up."
He said his name was Bill Hyman. He'd been holed up in the woods alone for some time, until he was kidnapped by "masked men" and taken to an underground facility where they drugged and experimented on him.
Sounds like an alien abduction fantasy, but his fear is sure real.
Ask him where the lab is

He scarfed three helpings of rice and beans, introducing himself as "Bill... mfmfmf... Bill Hyman" through mouthfuls.
"Wow, thanks guys." he said, rubbing his belly. "With food this good, I could eat like this all the time!"
Bill said he'd been holed up in the woods alone for some time, until he was kidnapped by "masked men" and taken to an underground facility where they drugged and experimented on him.
Sounds like an alien abduction fantasy, but his fear is sure real.
Ask him where the lab is

"Thanks friends." he said once he'd calmed down. "I'm a pretty fast healer, so a little ointment goes a long way."
He said his name was Bill Hyman. He'd been holed up in the woods alone for some time, until he was kidnapped by "masked men" and taken to an underground facility where they drugged and experimented on him.
Sounds like an alien abduction fantasy, but his fear is sure real.
Ask him where the lab is

[We] stormed through the HIVE lab, killed the last of Clark's zombie security personnel (the animal-masked researchers were either all dead or fled), then set enough explosives on Clark's vault door to level several city blocks.
He was still in there, shouting at [us] over the PA system.
"Fools! You'll never even scratch this vault! Did I say steel before? I meant titanium! Six feet of solid titanium! You should just give up and go ho-"
BOOOOooooom!

Sunlight streamed into the underground lab. [We] picked our way to Clark's remarkably intact vault (maybe it really was titanium). The door was ajar, but there was no sign of Clark. No way he escaped this... right?
Inside [we] found years of research on the disease. Early tests, a full breakdown of how it works, and a solid theory on how to produce a serum to cure it. Assuming we can find someone immune whose brain tissue we can use.
Jesse arrived with a couple Rotten. They want to know what we found.

"I'm afraid it's all Greek to me," said Jesse, "and I reckon your engineers don't have the equipment or experience to produce this cure neither. But I know who does. The Pharmacists."
"Rumor is they're setting up in Abbotsford, a couple towns west of here. We'll reconvene with you folks there. Gonna get myself cured, whoo-eee!" He tipped his hat and strode off.
He's right, we're going to need help to put this cure into production. Guess it's time to leave Hope and move on.

"Now, you still don't trust old Jesse?" he seemed hurt. "No matter. I reckon your engineers don't have the equipment or experience to produce this cure neither. But I know who does. The Pharmacists."
"Rumor is they're setting up in Abbotsford, a couple towns west of here. We'll see you folks there, whether you care to or not. Gonna get myself cured, whoo-eee!"
He tipped his hat to [us] and strolled away. He's right, we're going to need help to put this cure into production. Guess it's time to leave Hope and move on.

There was no sign over the lab's entrance, just an anonymous garage door set into a wall and hidden by some ferns. But this was it all right: a trail of recent footprints and wheel marks led up to it.
We couldn't find an easy way to open it, so we dismantled the hinges and wrenched the door off the wall. A small plaque on the back read: "Property of the _Hope Infectious Disease and Viral Experimentation Laboratory_"
Inside, the floor sloped steeply down into the darkness.

There was no sign over the lab's entrance, just an anonymous garage door set into a wall and hidden by some ferns. But this was it all right: a trail of recent footprints and wheel marks led up to it.
We couldn't find an easy way to open it, so we dismantled the hinges and wrenched the door off the wall. A small plaque on the back read: "Property of the _Hope Infectious Disease and Viral Experimentation Laboratory_"
We should return when we're prepared for whatever's down there. It will almost certainly be dangerous.

There was a cough behind us. When we turned to see Cassandra Starr standing there, a line of orange-robed cultists scurried across the entrance and formed a human wall.
"I'm afraid you're in our territory," Cassandra said evenly. "And your auras are far too tainted to trespass in such a holy place. You may return once you have cleansed yourselves and fully understand our teachings."
I think she wants more of us to become cultists...

The air in Hope is refreshingly pure and pine-scented. Their old city hall was still standing so we set up in it. Now to find that lab!
The Church of the Chosen Ones have their headquarters here. Maybe they've heard of this secret research lab and can tell us where to find it.

We landed our airplane in an old farm near Hope's city hall. Looks like the old Beaver's still ticking, so we can refuel and fly out once we find that lab.
The Church of the Chosen Ones have their headquarters here. Maybe they've heard of this secret research lab and can tell us where to find it.

The Church of the Chosen Ones... they're all dead. Their fort is destroyed; overrun after a ritual mass suicide. They all drank something, then rose back up as mindless zed.
All except Cassandra. We found her body in her office, dead from a shot to the head so she wouldn't turn like the rest of them. Did she never believe her own doctrine?
I can't say I didn't see this coming. We're just lucky it hasn't happened to us... yet. Luckily, this really scared {1} of our cultists straight.

he Church of the Chosen Ones... they're all dead. Their fort is destroyed; overrun after a ritual mass suicide. They all drank something, then rose back up as mindless zed.
All except Cassandra. We found her body in her office, dead from a shot to the head so she wouldn't turn like the rest of them. Did she never believe her own doctrine?
I can't say I didn't see this coming. We're just lucky it didn't happened to us.

The Church of the Chosen Ones no longer controls the underground laboratory, so we can now safely enter it.
Well, probably not safely. I mean, who knows what's still going on down there. We better bring some muscle, and maybe an engineer or two.
Mission available to Enter the Lab

I met [Name], our recovering laboratory guinea pig, planting trees along our main avenue.
"We don't really need these wide roads anymore, do we?" he asked. "I mean, no cars to drive on them. Might as well have some shade and fresh air here."
A few things had been bugging me about Bill's arrival at our fort. Now's my chance to ask him some questions.
What did they do to you in there?
Did you mention a zombie before?
Where do you think the lab was again?

"It's kind of foggy, but it seemed like there were a lot of needles involved. And a scalpel. I remember the scalpel. They said they were going to cut my brain up once they were finished with the rest of me."
He looked away to the side and rubbed his arm. "I can't imagine what they'd want with _me_, in particular. I mean, I'm just a regular guy..."

Bill nodded. "Oh yeah, one of them was definitely undead looking. Green skin and all that. But less with the biting and more with the science. He could still talk, I mean, and he seemed to be running things and giving orders to the others. He was pretty high strung, and mean."
"The rest all had these weird Halloween masks, like animals and stuff... I think. Unless I was just seeing things as a side effect from all the drugs... I guess that's possible, eh?"

"Like I said, I don't remember exactly. I hid in [a] {1} that must have been very close. I don't even remember getting to it, just waking up there.
I stumbled maybe {2} blocks in a straight line. It was dark and my memory's spotty, but I know I passed [a] {3}. There might have been something else. A wall? Then I hit the woods."
"I was planning to head back to my cabin, but realized they might know about it. I feel much safer here with you guys. Thanks for taking me in, by the way."

By the time [we] arrived at the cultists' [square], [we] could already hear fighting from inside their compound. It looks like Jesse and the Rotten came through.
They killed guards and opened gates from the inside, letting zombies rush in to feast on the very people who worshiped them. It was a bloodbath.
[We] spotted Jesse stalking through the streets with a pistol in each hand, totally ignored by the zombies feeding around him.

When I told Jesse we'd found the hidden lab but the Church of the Chosen Ones wouldn't let us inside, he sprang up and started pacing.
"Those cultists sure are crazier than a loon circus on a full moon, " he said, "but they've taken a liking to us Rotten. They think we're some kind of holy, on account of our _condition_. We could use that to take them down from the inside."
"Things are gonna get violent though. You okay with that?"
No, I don't want to hurt them

"Glad you agree." he nodded. "Worshiping zombies is unhealthy and unnatural. What the disease did to us... I'm looking to undo it, not repeat it. That's why we need the cure. To cure us."
"So, the plan: I'll tell the cultists we want to join them. They'll no doubt put us up like kings, at the cost of our dignity and sanity. Then, when your soldiers attack, we'll strike from the inside."
We shook on it. Now to attack the Church of the Chosen Ones and hope Jesse fills his end of the bargain.

"That's a shame." Jesse frowned. "You know they're fixing to make more folks like us, right? I'd bet donkeys to donuts that's what they need that cure for."
"We, on the other hand, just want to be human again. So think of old Jesse if you do get your hands on that cure somehow. Good luck, and hey:"
"Don't drink the Kool-Aid."

We passed a suspiciously familiar looking subway station today: a maze of piled up garbage around the entrance, painted with skulls and "do not enter" signs. But instead of hurling junk at us, this time the Rotten invited us in.
Jesse tipped his finger to his hat in greeting. "Howdy partners. I didn't expect your ugly pink mugs - no offence, mind - to turn up in this here little mountain town. What brings you to [CityName]?"
Say we're just here for the fresh air
Ask why the Rotten are here

"Well I'll be." Jesse laughed and rolled his eyes grotesquely. "A pinkskin accusing _me_ of experimenting on one of _their_ kind."
"Now I should be offended, but this is the sort of attitude we Rotten are used to from you folk. Nobody seems to get that we ain't evil."
"He says there was a Rotten there? Well, I'll swear to you that it wasn't one of us. I know, because we're here to find that lab too but don't have a clue where it is. Let us know if you find it."

"Oh sure," Jesse drawled. "This fresh mountain air's a real tonic for the constitution. Perks you up better than a shot of Tabasco in the eye."
"Well if you ain't sayin', then I ain't sayin' neither. But if you happen to come across some kind of underground facility type deal here in [CityName], let us know."
He winked. "We're looking for it too."

"The same reason you are." Jesse looked me straight in the eyes. "To find that lab and the cure for zombieism."
I was shocked at his honesty. We just started at each other for a minute.
"Listen," he said, "we'll help if we can, but right now we're as clueless as a camel at the North Pole... as regards to the location that is. So come back and let old Jesse know if you find the place."

Cassandra hugged me. "Congratulations again on having a majority of Chosen Ones followers." she said. "This grants you Clear Aura status among us... and access to many of our secrets."
I asked - predictably - if this meant she would finally tell us where their hidden underground lab was.
She smiled a slow, knowing smile. "I suppose... for a price."

Cassandra laughed. "Please tell me you didn't convert half of your people to my religion just so I'd tell you where that lab was."
When I didn't say anything, her smile got a little thinner. "The facility is under one of our [squares]. If you meet me there, I'll show you the way inside."
Mission available to Enter the Lab

Cassandra laughed. "Please tell me you didn't convert half of your people to my religion just so I'd tell you where that lab was."
When I didn't say anything, her smile got a little thinner. "The facility is under one of our [squares]. If you meet me there, I'll show you the way inside."
Mission available to Enter the Lab
Cassandra is still willing to tell us where that hidden lab is... for a price.

[We] confronted Cassandra on the "Living Osiris" thing. Clark is no god; he's a megalomaniac bent on ruling the world. How could pacifists like her church team up with such a psycho?
"Pacifism..." Cassandra mused. "Every day, you eat food that could have kept someone else alive. Every step you take, you crush countless tiny organisms beneath you. If you really don't want to hurt anyone or anything, just die and get out of their way."
I asked what that had to do with Clark's undead army, but she shook her head.

I remember those "Doctors Without Borders" from before everything went to hell. True heroes. There's a group visiting [CityName] who are doing something similar to help those people struggling against the zed. These traveling doctors are offering to treat our injured, or leave us some of their spare medicine.
There's also a third option... we could try to steal all their medicine for ourselves. After all, they're here to help the needy, and who else is more needy than us?

A little [woman|man] showed up at our fort today wearing [*a long white coat with a red cross crudely sewn onto it|a stethoscope and one of those old-fashioned head-mirrors|some rubber gloves and an unsettling grin]. [She|He]'s part of a group of traveling doctors trying to help people in this godforsaken country we now find ourselves in.
[She|He]'s offered to treat our injured, or leave us some of [her|his] spare medicine in case something goes wrong in future.
Or... we could just take all [her|his] medicine and throw [her|him] out on [her|his] ear. It doesn't look like [she|he]'d put up much of a fight...

A heavily armored ambulance [covered in barbed wire, with spikes on it's wheels|with gun barrels sticking out of every door and window|with a flame thrower mounted on its roof] just barreled through the zed and into our compound. It belongs to a group of benevolent doctors traveling the ruins of civilization.
They're offering to help our sick or leave us some of their spare medicine in case of emergencies. But... well... if they have so many medical supplies that they're just giving the stuff away, how much more do they have crammed in that ambulance of theirs?

Those doctors flew through our medical ward like a hurricane of gauze, pills, and spray-on skin. Before long every one of our injured was right as rain. Or at least good enough that we can put them back to work.
You can still work with your leg in a cast, right?
The docs left us some bandages, antiseptics, and syringes full of a strange green "cure-all". I just hope we don't need to use that stuff anytime soon.

I thought doctors were supposed to have some kind of "hypocritical oath" to not do harm or something... but they sure can get mean when riled up.
We tried to take all of their medicine for ourselves, but what we ended up with is 2 new bloody noses and broken bones. Now who is going to heal this lot?
We beat up those doctors and took all their stuff. That'll teach them to work towards the betterment of mankind with no thought as to their own reward.

I used to be a doctor, so I recognized the symptoms of [FormalName's] infected wound right away. Thankfully it wasn't a zombie bite, just your run-of-the-mill bacteria. But it could just as easily been fatal if I hadn't seen [him] limping and cleaned that wound properly. Even the slightest scratch needs to be looked at these days.

[FormalName] had a fever for the last couple nights that seemed to be getting worse. I had to dig way back in my brain to my medical school training to recognize it as Coccidioidomycosis, a fungal lung infection that usually affects farm workers. Coccidioidomycosis... I can't believe I still remember how to spell it!
A little athlete's foot medicine in an ashma sprayer and voila: cured.

It's amazing what bed rest will do in a properly sterile room without all those rat droppings covering the floor. [Name] was looking a little peaky, but after a couple of days in the hospital [he]'s all better.

We all found out today that [Name] is really really allergic to bee stings. [He] went into anaphylactic shock and stopped breathing, but [we] managed to get [him] to the hospital in time.
Had to stick a tube down [his] throat to help [him] breathe, and pumped [his] heart full of adrenaline. Good thing we had a sterile environment and the right tools to do it.

It's hard to take advantage of the benefits of modern medicine without a hospital. [Name's] starting to turn a nasty shade of green, but without the proper facilities to take care of [him], [he]'s just going to waste away in that bed of [hiss].
All we can do is cross our fingers and hope [he] recovers...

Is bleeding from the eyes normal? [Name's] started doing it recently, but without a hospital we've got no way of treating it. [He]'s complaining of really bad headaches too so I told [him] to take a few days off work.
Uh... I hope whatever it is isn't catching.

[Name] suddenly dropped to the ground holding [his] chest and made a sound like a snake in a blender. We think it was [his] heart, but without a hospital we had no way of confirming it. Miraculously [he] didn't die though... seems like [he]'s recovered, though [he]'s really wheezy now.
We're giving [him] bedrest, the only thing we can do.

[Name] was digging through old dumpster when a raccoon went after him. Think the thing must have been sick, 'cause within a couple of days [he] was hallucinating and yelling at the walls. [He]'s confined to bed... and quarantined for good measure.
If we had a hospital we might have been able to avoid this. All I can say is I hope it's not rabies, because you don't recover from rabies.

Looks like the European Center for Disease Control sent the Government a big data dump before the lines went dead.
Basically all their research on the infection is here. Early vectors, studies of its effect on the brain. And one promising trial of convalescent plasma serum from the blood of a resistant chimpanzee. They claim it worked on other chimps, but not on people. They needed to find a resistant human for that.
We're going to hold on to this data. Could be the key to a vaccine someday.

Senator Davis was giving orders to a group of soldiers when [we] arrived. They didn't seem happy about "graveyard duty", whatever that was, but she said she was following orders from her commanders in the federal government.
"We all have tough jobs to do, " she said, "now go do yours."

"Absolutely not, " she said, crossing her arms. "The network is not some series of tubes there for your amusement. It is for top secret government use only. If people started clogging it up by playing shooter games and watching Youtubes, important government emails might not get through. For the sake of national security, we can't have that."
The senator seems to be a dead end. Maybe someone else can help us?

[We] poked [our] head[s] into a few rooms. Soldiers: nope. More soldiers: nope. Politicians in heated argument: nope. Then off in a disused wing, we found a man hunched over a computer. He has shockingly pink hair, and seemed to be playing Minesweeper. Could be our ticket to network access. I stepped in and introduced myself.
"Oh. Hi." he said, quickly switching to a spreadsheet app, "My name's Andy. I'm the fort's IT guy. Uh... you probably shouldn't be in here."

[We] returned to the disused wing with the pink-haired IT guy, Andy. This time he was definitely playing Minesweeper when [we] came in. He turned his monitor off.
"Oh, hi again."

Andy was unimpressed. "Angry Birds? Candy Crush? Is that what you call gaming? I'm sorry buddy, we have nothing to talk about."
Maybe we should come back later with someone who knows their geek culture a little better.

"World of Goo, Fez, Rockets Rockets Rockets" Andy reminisced, "It was all about the indie games. I used to wish I made games, instead of sitting at this desk plunking away at a terrible Windows server architecture and waiting for my pension."
"The network? Nah, not from this computer. They blocked it long before the outbreak: first Facebook, then game and news sites; soon the Internet was nothing but Net Nanny notices. The only machine that still has uncensored access is Senator Davis' private computer."
Well, at least we found out the Operating System.

"Listen, " Andy said, "you can pronounce it linn-ix or lie-nucks, but not whatever you just said. Do you even know what an operating system is?"
Maybe we should come back later with someone who knows their geek culture a little better.

"I liked Slackware too, " said Andy. "Or Mint for gaming. But we're all 'Microsoft Windows Enterprise Solutions' here at the government." he smacked his monitor.
"The network? Nah, not from this computer. They blocked it long before the outbreak: first Facebook, then game and news sites; soon the Internet was nothing but Net Nanny notices. The only machine that still has uncensored access is Senator Davis' private computer. But she'd never let you in there, sorry."
Well, at least we found out the Operating System.

Sounds like that military coup is going down at the Government fort. The one we're pretty much directly responsible for. The two factions must be evenly matched, because they've been at it all day, blowing each other up with their big effing guns.
Are we going to pick a side?

We tried to stay out of the violence, acting as long-distance scouts for Senator Davis and his rebels. With our help, they could react to the senator's forces quickly, and did so by demolishing up anything in the vicinity with extreme prejudice.
The Government fort was such a mess by the time it was over that it wasn't clear _what_ they'd won, if anything. After a long meeting, it was decided the survivors would pack up and move on to another, less destroyed city. We wished them well.

Senator Davis was surprised to see us on her side. Honestly, I just didn't want the Government run by someone even more militaristic than she was.
We joined in the fighting. [FormalName] was shot in the shoulder while personally guarding the senator, right in the thick of things. Davis had been a marine in her youth and still remembered her training.
We won. Luckily we had no casualties, though the same can't be said for Davis' troops. Their base also took heavy damage... but with our help they can rebuild it.

We tried to lay low until they finished demolishing the place, but the occasional stray RPG still came over our walls. Then one of them landed _on_ the walls, and we lost a {1}.
After several days of this, the two sides declared a truce among the wreckage. We could see them shaking hands, then going their separate ways: the two groups leaving the city in different directions.
War: what is it good for?

We met some 1337cREw members leaving the city today, wearing backpacks and looking beaten half to death.
"I dunno how," Dara said, "but they knew we were listening. We intercepted a message from their scouts... A motherload of undefended fuel and electronics. Jackpot, right? We came to snatch it from them like usual, but they were waiting. The Deathstar was fully operational."
"They locked us inside, and the zed... most of my people are dead. The rest are getting as far from the Government as we can. We opened our gates, let the zed in. They can have it."

I came to the Government's base hoping to find Andy Moore and check on his progress with the video game, but before I could, Senator Davis herded me back outside. She reminding me of our "patriotic duties to the state" and that house we'd been asked to scavenge.

I watched eagerly as Dara parsed through the data we'd collected. She seemed to get more and more frustrated.
"There's nothing here!" she finally shouted. "No network at all! No trace of any connection. The senator hasn't even gotten an email in years... she's just been lying to everyone so they'll follow her orders."
She tossed me back the USB stick and pouted. "The last thing they sent her was an encrypted dump from some Euro agency. If you want it you can decrypt it yourself. I'm done with this."
Ask if Andy can join them
"Andy who?" Dara was skeptical. "That pink haired dude? Does he have the chops?"
"Yeah, " she agreed, "I guess you guys have been solid, and Andy did put himself at risk for this even though it was a total shnozhonk. You tell him he's got a place in the Crew if he wants it."

"Bwah, no!" Dara rolled her eyes at me. "The last thing the Crew need is another script kiddie who thinks he's a hacker just because he plugged a drive in. We've got enough of those already."
I guess risking your life to help these guys isn't enough to get you into the 1337cREw. Sorry Andy.
"Yeah, " she agreed, "I guess Andy did put himself at risk for this even though it was a total shnozhonk. You tell him he's got a place in the Crew if he wants it."

I confronted Senator Davis, accusing her of lying about the network so she could make up orders from nonexistant bosses at the federal government.
She caved almost immediately, like she'd been expecting this. "Yes, " she admitted, "we are the only branch of the government that still exists, to my knowledge. Someone needed to make the hard decisions... and it was easier for people to believe that person was halfway across the continent."
"Listen, if people found out, there could be a coup. Please... these people need me. They need the lie."

I stormed out of the office and right into Andy. I yelled "The network is a lie!" and he answered "I know! Well... I always suspected!".
We marched down to the cantina where soldiers were gathering for lunch break. "The network is a lie!" we yelled in unison.
We continued on this like this as people stopped and stared, whispering and looking nervously at one another. You could see them starting to take sides, those who'd back the senator and those who'd been looking for an excuse to remove her. We'll have to wait and see what happens in the coming days.
Ask Andy what he'll do now

He seemed optimistic that things would turn out well for the Government. "If she holds on to power, at least it will be honestly. But my money's on the other guy." He gestured at a man in a general's uniform.
"No offence, " he said, "but it's my best option. I mean, the way you operate... you guys don't seem much better than the old boss."
I guess I should be insulted? But we shook hands and I wished him well.

"Leet Crew Eff-tee-double-yew!" he pronounced it without a trace of irony. "The Crew sent me notice, I'm in! I'm getting out of here right now, before shots start flying."
We shook hands and I wished him well. Glad we could help a guy out... I just hope he doesn't get into any trouble over there.

"Well, " he said sheepishly, "I was hoping you guys might have room for an engineer with a penchant for video games? Maybe a programming position?"
I doubt we have any need for programmers, but I welcomed Andy to join us anyway. Turns out he's also a pilot, in case that ever comes up.

"Thank God." she sighed, visibly relieved. Then: "Andy Moore, you can come in now!" Andy slouched in, looking guilty. Davis sighed again. "I caught this man installing unauthorized software onto my computer. You wouldn't know anything about this, would you...?"
"...Of course you wouldn't. Well Mr Moore, I'm promoting you to first corporal of the wall. Head to the barracks for your uniform and gun."
Andy looked at [us] desperately, pleading for an intervention.
Ask if Andy can join us instead

"The hacker clan?" she mused, "I suppose they must have put him up to it."
I added that they'd been listening in on the Government's radio broadcasts and poaching their scavenging sites. "Yes," she said, "those cyber-terrorists have been on our watchlist for awhile. Well.. I guess there's no reason to waste a mind like Mr Moore's on this breach of security. We'll just have to keep a closer eye on him and his computers."
Andy glared at [us], furious at [our] betrayal. Hey, at least he got to keep his job and his pension, right?

"The hacker clan?" she mused, "I suppose they must have put him up to it."
I added that they'd been listening in on the Government's radio broadcasts and poaching their scavenging sites. "Yes," she said, "I'm glad we took out those cyber-terrorists when we had the chance. Well.. I guess there's no reason to waste a mind like Mr Moore's on this breach of security. We'll just have to keep a closer eye on him and his computers."
Andy glared at [us], furious at [our] betrayal. Hey, at least he got to keep his job and his pension, right?

Andy stepped in. "Actually, " he said, "I'm mad as hell with the way you guys took advantage of me, and I don't have to take it anymore. I'm through with being a pawn or a passive consumer. I'm going to take action in my life, pick up a gun and take my chances on the wall."

Davis frowned and closed her eyes to think. "I suppose... " she said, "you have shown yourselves to be allies today. And it would get him away from our computers... Okay. You can have him."
Andy looked ready to burst from joy. "I hope you need an engineer, or a video game designer." He grinned. "I also have my pilot's license if that's useful."
"And, " he laughed "I'm awful good at Microsoft Solitaire."

Andy slumped off to the barracks hopelessly. I feel back for the guy, but at least he'll be doing something useful there instead of just playing games all day in an office. Hopefully he'll adapt, like we all have.

Looks like the 1337cREw beat us to the punch like last time. The backyard bunker was huge, easily a four-person deal. A legacy of the cold war, or some doomsday prepper who must have died before they could get to it. But empty. Just a note on the floor that said "Pwned again. - Cryptico"
I guess we could search the rest of the house. The Government didn't mention it.

I snuck over to Andy's office after the meeting. Turns out he loved the game we gave them, and couldn't stop raving about it.
"It was totally worth the chance of getting caught on her computer," he said, returning the USB drive. "But don't worry, she doesn't suspect a thing."
The drive felt heavy in my hand with the important data it held. We should bring it back to the 1337cREw as soon as we can.

I snuck over to Andy's office after the meeting. He was giddy from his first stab at government espionage.
"Sup comrades! I totally hacked that data you wanted off the senator's computer. I plugged this baby in and just let her do the work." He handed back the USB stick. "It's all on there, what the 1337cREw need to know. So... you're going to tell them I want to join, right? I could be a great hacker, I think this is what I was born for."
I gave him the thumbs up.

[We] found the building's former owners lying in bed together, two parents and two kids with stained sheets pulled up to their chins. Looks like they'd taken pills rather than use that bunker outside.
As I was leaning over to read the label on the pill bottle, one of the children opened its eyes and snapped at me. It wormed its way out of the covers and lunged.
Startled and disturbed, [we] booked it out of there. No way [we're] going back. I need a couple days just to get my head straight after that experience.

[We] found some food in the kitchen. Upstairs, the building's former owners were lying in bed together, dead of an overdose of sleeping pills. Two parents and two kids, lined up like dwarves in a fairy tale, the sheets pulled up to their chins.
We made sure they were dead just in case, then took what pills were left in the cabinets.

"What's this?" asked Andy when I dropped the USB stick in his hands. I told him it was only the hottest game the world's been anticipating since the dead started chomping.
"It's not a zombie game, is it?" He looked dubious. "I've had enough of those... and what do you mean it's always online, that doesn't make any sense... I mean their servers..."
"Oh you're back." Andy was just staring at the wall when we met him this time. He looked dangerously, desperately bored. "Did you bring that game?"

I bumped into the Senator on the way out of Andy's office. I hope my fright wasn't too obvious.
"There you are, " she said. "We need your service to the Government again, citizen[s]. Our scouts have located a supply cache hidden in a bunker in a suburban backyard. Its contents need to be salvaged and brought to us ASAP. Here's the briefing."
She didn't wait for my reply, just shoved a folder into my hand then turned on her heel and marched away.
Convince him the game is great (engineering)

"Uh, no, I've heard of those guys," said Andy. "Cyber-terrorists they say. Sounds like a hard life. Probably no benefits. I think you should take your game back and go."
Maybe we could send someone else to convince him.

I told him the truth. There was malware on the USB drive, and the 1337cREw wanted to use it to get access to the Government's network. In exchange for helping us, I said, I'd put in the good word for him with the 1337cREw.
He perked up at this. "They'd let me do actual programming instead of sitting around doing nothing? Alright, screw my pension, let's do this."
"Come back in a week and I'll have your access data."

I guess I failed to convince him. "Good games are about more than the graphics," he said. "They have to do something different, they have to pull you in and speak to you. You should take your game back and go... I'm really busy."
Clearly he isn't. We should send someone else to talk to him in a few days, maybe he'll change his mind.

Andy was convinced. "Man, this game sounds amazing. It's too bad about the DRM, but as soon as Senator Davis goes home for the night I'm going to load it up on her machine. Don't worry, she'll never know."
"Come back next week and we can talk about the game!"

This scared him. "Don't tell my boss. If they find out I'm doing nothing in here all day, they'll put me on the wall. I'm a thinker, not a soldier. I'd die out there!"
I pressed him until he caved. "Okay, okay, I'll play your game on the Senator's computer. I'll... I'll tell you what I think of it next time we meet."

Senator Davis had a special request for us during our meeting. Well, "request" isn't quite the right word. She says she now has authority from head office to conscript any local citizens to serve the Government. This just came over on "the network" from the federal government back east. She said we could take it up with them if we have a problem with it.
These guys have power and the Internet? Wow they really are connected.
Ask how we contact the feds

Davis nodded. "Thank you for your loyal service, citizens."
She said their scouts had radioed in that an office tower in the financial district is ready to be scavenged. We should find at least three truckloads of supplies there that the government needs. Our mission is send our best scavengers, retrieve the supplies and bring them back here.

Davis frowned. "Did I say you had a choice?"
She said their scouts had radioed in that an office tower in the financial district is ready to be scavenged. We should find at least three truckloads of supplies there that the government needs. Our mission is send our best scavengers, retrieve the supplies and bring them back here.

She was clearly ready for this one. "Access to secure communication channels with federal offices is restricted," she said. "and use of the network is for authorized personnel only... I'm afraid your security clearance level is too low to allow it."
[We] told Dara [we] were here to meet with Cryptico. She put her hands on her hips and said "Okay, did you bring a present?"

Dara accepted the gift. "Okay, so, I'm Cryptico, " she said. "Like that wasn't super obvious, right? It's my handle, it's what the Crew call me."
"So, we've decoded the Government radio channels and we've been listening in. That's how we knew about the office tower, and about you, and one more thing."
"The Government have this thing called the network. It's the Internet, right? Invented in the 80s so they'd have a way to talk to the feds if something crazy happened. You know, crazy like the zombpocalypse, right?"

"So, we want back online! Communication is a basic human right, okay? We had this thing called net neutrality once but we lost it because we didn't fight for it. Now the Government has access to the network and we plebs don't. We don't even know what's going on in the east. That's not ethical! It's not right! Right?"
I nodded, though I wasn't sure. She continued. "Okay, so we know they like you. So poke around, try to learn about their system. Send an engineer next time you meet with them. At least find out what Operating System they use."
What would someone named Cryptico like? A book about ciphers? A secret decryptor ring? Or is it "crypt" as in graveyards and stuff?

We found a letter slipped through our gates this morning, in the same printed typeface as the one from the office tower. It read:
"Hail, Government lackeys. I know you work for them. And I know other things. And those things, you want to know them too. If you've got the cojones to meet, find me at the 1337cREw compound. Come in the PM; I'm not a morning person. And bring prezzies. - Cryptico"
Wonder what Cryptico means by "prezzies". Flowers and chocolate?

I gave Dara the bad news: only one computer at the Government can reach the network, and we can't get to it.
"Wait, " she was hopeful, "you said the pink-haired dude has access, right? He doesn't need to get _us_ in, just _this_." She pulled out a USB stick. "If he plugs it in, it'll snoop around and download the deets to that secure connection."
"He likes games, right? Let's put one on this and tell him it'll only run on the Senator's machine. He plugs it in to play, and boom goes the dynamite. Boom! So, which of these games do we use?"

Dara loaded the game up onto the USB drive. "Yeah, this game was still in beta when the world went to hell, but I was a playtester. The whole world was dying for it to come out. Haha, right? Anyway I bet he never got to play it."
"Tell him this game needs to be always online cuz of DRM, so it needs a connection to the network. Make him believe, okay? We need this."
She handed me the drive. "May the force be with you, [brother]."

Davis was quite upset about the missing bunker and weapons. She threw up her arms. "How is this possible? Our scouts just found that cache!"
She narrowed her eyes at me when I didn't reply. "No, seriously. Where are my weapons?"
Deliver food and medicine we found

I promised her this was all we'd found.
"I suppose this will have to do, " she sighed. "Thank you for your report. The Government will take it from here."

"The who now?" She leaned in. "Are they protecting that Cryptico? Was there another note?"
I explained that the 1337cREw had been listening in to the radio reports from their scouts, and had cracked the code they use. I left out the part about the network and the USB drive.
The senator was creepily calm about it. She just thanked [us] for [our] report and dismissed [us].

I told her there was nothing there when we arrived and that was all I knew. I didn't mention the note from Cryptico this time.
The senator didn't believe me, but she let [us] go.
"We're keeping an eye on your group, citizen. If it turns out you've kept those weapons for your own use, you are going to seriously regret it."

It's a shame the 1337cREw couldn't find what they wanted on the Government network. They seemed like smart kids, though their compound had a bit of a college dorm kind of vibe.
Reminds me of my own time at college. I...
graduated at the top of the class
partied and had a great time
dropped out after a few months
If I had to do it all over again, I would...
Drop out to play video games
Do it all exactly the same

I've always had an interest in medicine, but found the ungodly amount of education required pretty daunting. Twelve extra years of studying, tests, and internship before I could even start a practice.
But I think I'd be ready for it now. I've decided to take it on myself to start studying medicine. I'm going to try to become the doctor I never was.

Why ever leave? I could take courses on french poetry, the philosophy of Star Trek, feminism in pop music, vampire film studies... I could learn sign language or Esperanto or how to build Haida bentwood boxes.
You know what? We've got books and experts on strange subjects here. I'm going to take myself back to school and try to learn a new subject every month.

They say professional e-sports competitors reach their prime at 19. The full-time training required to reach the top leaderboards don't leave much room for college. Parents just don't understand!
But you know, we've got enough generator power to play video games in the evenings. Maybe it's not too late for me to get back into that noble realm. The problem will be finding someone to compete against...
I have no regrets. I've lived my life the way that felt right at the time. It's all kind of a blur now anyway since the infection. We've all got more pressing things to worry about than the past.

[We] spent hours combing through the office tower the Government assigned us to scavenge, climbing stairs until my legs were ready to collapse. But [we] found nothing useful whatsoever, not even coffee in the break rooms.
It was clear by the 5th floor that someone had beaten us to this place, but [we] persisted to the top. In the CEO's office, alone on the massive oak desk, [we] found a note:
"Lulz, beat you to it! - Cryptico"

Senator Davis read the note and mulled it over. "How could they have known... " she wondered. "The scouts only radioed in the location a few days before..."
"Well, it looks like like 'Cryptico' might be a possible threat. Might be an individual, or some sort of terrorist organization with an agenda to undermine the Government. Keep an eye out for them."
"Oh, and good work citizen[s]. I will let you know when we have your next assignment."

[We] [were] picking [our] way through the rubble at the subway entrance when there was a click at my back and a voice said "If you're looking for trouble, friend, I'll accommodate ya."
I turned around slowly... and nearly crapped myself. It was a zombie! A zombie pointing a revolver at me and grinning.
"Hold on there pardner," he said in an obviously fake John Wayne drawl, "this here's our spread, an' yer trespassin' on it". He was dressed the part in a trenchcoat and cowboy hat. A talking freaking zombie in a cowboy hat.

[We] made our way through makeshift defenses, basically anything heavy that could be piled up in front of the subway entrance.
A figure in a long trenchcoat appeared at the bottom of the stairs.
"Howdy friend[s]." he spoke through his teeth, a cigar in the corner of his mouth. "I've been wondering when you would show."
It was Jesse, leader of the Rotten. Not quite dead, not quite right in the head...

Jesse relaxed and took his hands out of his coat pockets. I realized he'd had a pistol pointed at [us] until now.
"So, you're setting up in [CityName] too," he said. "Hope you aren't fixing to start any trouble in these parts."
He gave me a good long look in the eyes then nodded. "We Rotten have staked our claim on everything under the streets, and have the means to defend it if pressed. You stay clear and we won't have any trouble."

Before [we] could even draw, Jesse was raining bullets at [us] from his dual pistols. He must have had them pointed [our] way from under his coat.
The other Rotten poured out of the subway and forced [us] back out to the street. [We] retreated.
We've made an enemy.

Other zombies started shambling up all around us, but they weren't attacking, just kind of watching us and this crazy Clint Eastwood wannabe.
"They call us the Rotten," he tipped his hat with his pistol. "My name's Jesse. We won't be wronged. We won't be insulted. We won't be laid a hand on. We don't do these things to other people and we require the same from them. Now get off our land." He gestured at me with his gun.
I was getting nervous about the gathering ghouls, when one of them who'd come up from behind suddenly laid a hand on my shoulder.

[We] shot up those zombies good, until [we] saw they were screaming and covering their faces with their hands, like innocent people attacked by strangers who broke into their home and... uh-oh.
Then the ones with weapons got mad. They charged [us], swinging metal pipes and clubs and hurling pieces of subway turnstiles. They yelled obscenities in a very un-zombielike way. [We] beat a retreat.
The last thing [we] heard as [we] ran out of there was Jesse cursing us. I think we've made an enemy.

They were wary of us, but some told their stories. They'd been bitten by regular zed, got the fever, and fell asleep for what they thought was the last time... then woke up. They were dead, yet still themselves.
Mostly. Some of these creatures are pretty brain damaged. Their speech is slurred, they move sluggishly, they're easily confused. Jesse's clearly a few horses short of a rodeo. And they're prone to mood swings. One of them nearly bit my head off - literally - when I called him a zombie. I'm not comfortable with these... whatever they are... living so close to us, but we may have no choice.

The strange zombies, or whatever they are, were relieved when [we] left. A toothless man with one arm spat on the ground behind [us] to say "good riddance".
Jesse followed to make sure [we] [were] really going. "Listen pardner," he said, "I'll give you some advice: never kick a cow patty on a hot day."
He nodded meaningfully, like I had any clue what he meant.

Father O'Grady and some of the Judgment boys showed up at our gate this morning with long faces and empty gas canisters in their bikes.
Seems they burn through a lot of fuel driving around the city and were hoping we had a little to spare.

One of our scouts just spotted a group of grumpy-lookin' Last Judgment members not far from our walls. It looks like their bikes ran out of juice and they've been stranded there for the past couple of hours.
We could probably help them out if we had a bit of gas to spare.
Let them use your gas station
They were grateful for the gas and soon after we heard the sound of their engines revving in the distance.

I thought that gas station was dried right up, but they managed to siphon enough dregs from the bottom of the tanks to get themselves home. Father O'Grady said a little prayer over the station's pumps, they all touched the gasoline to their foreheads and crossed themselves, then one of them fired his gun in the air. I guess our gas station is blessed now?
They left empty-handed and lookin' depressed. They abandoned their bikes somewhere. Chances are those things'll soon look just like all the other rusted metal husks littering the streets.

We saw a bunch of bikers tearing through a pack of zombies like a hot knife through butter. If the knife was large, ugly and covered in religious symbols, that is.
Seems they're called the Last Judgment Gang. Claim to be following the way of God, but given the way they were dragging that survivor behind them as they drove through city streets I'm guessing "Love thy fellow man" isn't high on their list of priorities.
We'll probably have to deal with them before long, either by making nice or by clearing them out of town.

Figures a bunch of heavily-armed bikers would be tough enough to survive the end of the world. I just wouldn't have expected the biggest group of them to be Bible thumpers too.
The Last Judgment Gang are nasty bunch. The sort that are convinced that they are always in the right, no matter how violent, underhanded or misogynistic their actions are.
The idea of making friends with them rubs me the wrong way, but we need all the help we can get out here.

I wouldn't have crossed the Last Judgment Gang even back when there were still police to protect us. Now that there isn't much in the way of civilization left... steer clear.
They're a gang of bikers who follow the word of God... when it suits them. They're quick with Bible quotes on how wives should submit to their husbands, but they ignore the bits about not violently murdering thy neighbor. I'm pretty sure that's in there.
These guys worry me as much as the zed do, but at least we might be able to cut a deal with the Judgment.

I met with Father O'Grady to talk about setting up a no man's land between us and the Last Judgment. He pulled me aside at one point and told me he'd heard our new policy on "letting women out of the kitchen" as he put it. He said:
"It's good you're nipping that in the bud, [sonny]. You start giving women guns, and in my experience they'll just turn around and point them at ya."
"[Timothy 2:11, 'A woman should learn in quietness and full submission.'|Genesis 3:16, 'Thy desire shall be to thy husband, and he shall rule over thee.'|1 Timothy 2:12, 'I suffer not a woman to teach, nor to usurp authority over the man, but to be in silence.'|Ephesians 5:22, 'Let wives be in subjection to their husbands as to the Lord']"

I met with Father O'Grady to talk about setting up a no man's land between us and the Last Judgment. He pulled me aside at one point and told me he'd heard our new policy on "letting women out of the kitchen" as he put it. He said:
"You're making a serious mistake, [sonny]. The lord was clear on what a woman's role should be, and that's back home where she's safe with a man to protect her."
"[Timothy 2:11, 'A woman should learn in quietness and full submission.'|Genesis 3:16, 'Thy desire shall be to thy husband, and he shall rule over thee.'|1 Timothy 2:12, 'I suffer not a woman to teach, nor to usurp authority over the man, but to be in silence.'|Ephesians 5:22, 'Let wives be in subjection to their husbands as to the Lord']"

Father O'Grady and some of his Last Judgment bikers rode up to our gate today. [He got up on a crate and started preaching loudly over our walls.|They seem to be nailing crosses to our outer walls.|Now they're lounging around out there, drinking what looks like sacramental wine.]
I'm not entirely sure, but I think they may be trying to get us convert.

We got a knock on our gates today and opened it to find Father O'Grady with [some bored-looking men with ugly mustaches and biker leathers|two uncomfortable-looking women in historically inaccurate and embarassingly tight nun outfits|another clean-shaven man in a white shirt, leather vest and a tie with little crosses on it].
They asked if we'd "heard the Word of our Lord."

The Last Judgment cleared out some zed and set up a little campsite not far from our gate. Since then they've been [singing hyms. Or torturing cats. I'm not sure which.|stopping anyone who tries to leave our fort to invite them for a Bible reading.|calling any men they see over for drinks and yelling abuse at passing women.]
I think they're trying to get our attention, but they're doing it in the most obnoxious way possible.
Invite them to visit our church
Listen to what they have to say

The group seemed surprised that we actually might have a spiritual side. We showed them around the old church we had fixed up and bonded a little. Father O'Grady invited us to visit them so they could return the favor. This Sunday's sermon is on "[the evils of loose women|Jesus and His disciples: the world's first biker gang|God's flaming sword of justice, the M4 Carbine AR-15]." {1}
Our most devout survivors were pleased to host some fellow Christians for the day.

The group spent hours preaching to us, going over all the rules and regulations we need to follow if we want to avoid a fiery burning eternity after the cold grave. They eventually left looking satisfied.
When we made it clear that we weren't interested in what they had to say, they packed up and left. They didn't seem happy about it. {1}
Our most devout survivors were upset that we turned away fellow Christians.
