"Help old Two-Arms Reginald out, would ya [son]?" he wheezed. He was a one of the Rotten: green decaying flesh, missing teeth, terrible breath. And I noticed the arm he was begging with wasn't even attached to his body; he was holding it with his other hand.
What should I give him?

He seemed disappointed. "What's a Rotten like me supposed to do with [an apple|this bread|astronaut ice cream]? You're teasing old Reginald, ain't ya?"
He sighed and shrugged hopelessly, but he did keep the food, and wandered off into the city mumbling to himself.

This made him angry. "Pills??" He hollered and I dodged a spray of spittle. "Where were the pills when I got bit, huh? Where were they when I felt the fever, and when my teeth came out? And my arm! My arm! It's too, too, TOO LATE!"
He threw the medicine back through the crack at me and stormed away.

He rectracted his severed hand and eyed the prize. "Shiny bits of death," he murmured approvingly. He rolled the bullets around, mumbling and caressing them. He seemed to have completely forgotten I was there, but I guess he's happy.

Reggie stayed at the wall for the rest of the afternoon, smiling and winking at everyone who walked by, thrusting his dismembered arm through the crack at them and laughing wheezily when they jumped in fear.
Eventually he gave up and went home empty handed.

A couple bedraggled looking survivors are begging to join our fort. They look like they've been living on the edge of starvation for a long time.
One of them said [he] saw our searchlights last night from the edge of town and thought it was a sign from heaven.

Two very cheery people are at the gates asking if they can join us. They say they saw our searchlights lighting up the sky last night and thought [CityName] looked like a pretty happening place to live.
It guess it is... if by "happening" they mean "still scraping by and holding on for dear life despite the odds."
Those searchlights really were a good idea I guess. I told [Name] and [Name2] they're welcome to stay with us as long as they like.
They were pretty bummed out that we had to turn them away, but after seeing the state of things here they weren't too surprised.

A [man] named [FormalName] showed up today. [He] says [he] followed the murals pointing the way to our fort from the edge of the city. I didn't even know we had them out that far, but it's a good thing. We could use more [job]s like [Name].

This [job] named [FormalName] arrived at the gates and asked to join us today. [He] says [he]'d been admiring our murals all around town for a couple days and figured we must be pretty organized to advertise like that.

[Name] was upset that we didn't have a place for [him] here. [He] complained of false advertising, saying our murals claimed we were an "open community" with "space for everyone". I explained that times had changed, and [he] better get a move on before somebody got hurt.
The [man] never saw it coming. I told [him] we'd start the grand tour in our kitchens, where [Name2] was waiting with a meat cleaver to do the job. Quick work.

[He] didn't seem like a bad [man], but the needs of the many outweigh the needs of the few. And [his] body will feed many mouths and keep our children alive for one more month.
We must survive.
At any price.
The [man]'s screams will haunt my dreams tonight, but we did what needed to be done to survive. Some of the others don't know... but I think they're starting to suspect.
[We] found [a] half-starved {1} while out scavenging and named the little guy {2}. One of us could adopt him as a pet.
[We] found [a] {1} in the [square] that could be put to good use by one of our survivors.

[FactionLeader] has an urge for destruction. [FactionHe] keeps talking about the many uses of explosives and of all the problems that could be solved with a little TNT. If we could supply [faction] with a couple bombs, I think [factionHe]'d make good use of them.
[FactionLeader] identified a few key "trouble spots" and blew them off the face of the earth.

Like a creeper in a glass castle, [FactionLeader] wrecked havoc on the buildings around their fort. It seemed to backfire a bit, as they lost some useful potential buildings and their contents in the process. This might have weakened [faction] in the long run, but at least [factionHe] had fun.
[FactionLeader] still wants to blow something up.

Apparently [faction] are impressed by the architecture of our city hall. [FactionLeader] thinks it's amazing that you can't even tell it's cobbled together from scraps and bits of other buildings.
[FactionHe] wants our builders to make something for them. A {1}, which they want to put over a dilapidated old [square] in their fort. They'll supply the materials if we can supply the manpower.

[We] did an alright job building this [square] for [faction]. I guess. Okay okay... I admit [we] didn't really put [our] heart[s] into this one.
I mean, why are we building stuff for [faction] anyway? Whose idea was this?
Demand payment for work done (lvl 6 leader)

[FactionLeader] was impressed we finished it so quickly. [FactionLeader] wondered how much of the old building was still under there, and where we got the decorative moldings from, but I wouldn't tell. Trade secrets.
[FactionLeader] thought we were a bit foolish to ask for payment _after_ finishing the work, but [we] convinced [factionHim] we deserved it.
[FactionLeader] is still hoping we can build that {1}.

"We are hosting our yearly Festival of Meats soon, to honor the Chosen Ones outside our walls." Cassandra told me.
"Would you like to attend? We only require one attractor device to perform the ceremony."

"Clear your mind." Cassandra told me. "Make it completely empty of thought. Good. Now, imagine a world with no more stress, no confusion. A world where every being knows its purpose. You know yours. It is to spread... this message of peace."
"Not too bad, right?" she brought me back to the real world. "_This_ is the future the Chosen Ones are here to bring us. Have your people learned this message?"
She expects at least half of our survivors to be followers of their cult... I mean church.

Cassandra was pleased. "Of course, my children. And have each of you been in this month for one of our aura metering session? Regular metering is the only proven way to progress your aura forward to the next ring of awareness."
I told her mine would have to wait until my next visit.

[We] told her we have many more followers at our fort, but they have already fully embraced the Chosen Ones and been converted. In short, they're zombies now.
She believed [us]. She asked a bunch of excited questions about the details of their "conversions". Rather morbid really, even though I was just making it up.

The Church of the Chosen Ones would like our survivors to join their cult. We can't just force them to convert... but if we encourage their ceremonies and assign cultists to work beside non-cultists long enough, they may spread the message.

The meats and attractor devices were lined up along the Church's walls. Undead wandered in during the day while we mingled and celebrated.
By evening there was a sea of them out there, pressing shoulder to shoulder, grasping for our offerings.
We lit candles and solemnly stood watch over the Chosen ones while Cassandra prayed for them. [FormalName] was entranced by the ceremony. I think we have a convert.

It was... disgusting. They put attractors along the top of their wall, just out of reach of the zombies' grasping hands. Then we climbed up there and watched them while Cassandra prayed.
[We] pretended to be into it, but secretly sabotaged part of the wall so the attractors would fall off. I... I didn't know there would be people up there too. When the wall crumbled and that woman fell into the zombies...
The rest of them cheered. Like they were expecting it to happen. Like they were happy for her...
"Will you be able to attend our Festival of Meats?" Cassandra wanted to know. "Do you have the attractor we spoke of before?"

[Faction] are hosting a city-wide conference to discuss matters of inter-faction relations and the future of [CityName].
Well that's how [FactionLeader] tried to explain it to me... but actually they just want us to go and nod our heads while they declare how they think things should be done. Who should we send?
[Faction] enjoyed [Name]'s head nodding so much they made [him] an honorary [factionAdjective] member. [He]'ll be able to call in favors from them, if that ever comes up.
[Faction] enjoyed [Name2]'s head nodding so much they made [him2] an honorary [factionAdjective] member. [He2]'ll be able to call in favors from them, if that ever comes up.
[FactionLeader] is still waiting for us to choose a delegate to attend their "conference".

Cassandra was in a rare salesman mood. "I believe you are due to take the next one of our Advanced Courses. Spiritual well-being is more important than anything. Personal belongings, resources, buildings, weapons, food, all are transitory and impermanent. Our Advanced Courses are infinitely valuable and trascend time itself. Only 10 food per level."
"Only 10 food per level."

Cassandra attached a group of us to odd lie detector machines, then began the lecture. Cultists monitored the machines and took notes on our reactions.
"The Chosen Ones have auras like you and I, you know; it is what animates them once their hearts stop beating. We have metered them to prove it, just like we are metering you now."
"Now, imagine you are in a desert. There is a Chosen One nearby, but he has no legs. He is flailing, starving in the heat. Someone must help him..."

They connected a group of us to the machines that monitor our auras, which look like voltmeters. Do auras have an electric current? I'll have to ask.
I was focused; my breathing controlled. I absorbed the course content with maximum efficiency, and their metering machines pronounced my aura to be nearly perfect.
Even Cassandra was impressed at the intensity of my concentration.
Cassandra still wants us to pay 10 food to take a course on spirituality with them.

"What's the point of living in the ruins of a civilization," Ms McClung asked, "if you don't stretch out and enjoy the free space?"
We were touring their fort, which feels more like a gated retirement community than the military compound it is.
"There are enough empty homes for each of us to own two. If you agree, you should have empty room for at least 10 new survivors at your fort."
[We] told Nell she's right; we might as well take advantage of the vacated buildings and live in luxury.
"Really? You think that's enough?" she asked. "Well, I suppose not _everyone_ needs a fabulous second house... just your leaders, am I right?" she winked.
Nell is still waiting to see us have 10 empty homes.

Nell wants "I rarely go outside the walls anymore," Nell said. "I'm far too important to the Dahlias to put myself in needless danger... so I've got a request for you."
"I want you to fetch [some fabulous expensive jewelry|a new chandelier for our meeting hall|some bloodstain-free satin pillows] and whatever other luxury goods you can find in this one particular [square]."
She said she'd pay our scavengers 5 food when we return.

The gold reserve isn't really a thing anymore... at last check, a tin of tuna fish was going for twice its weight in gold jewelry. But some of us still hold on to those old ideas of the value of precious metals, and hey, they are pretty.
We scooped up enough luxury items at this [square] to fill a wheelbarrow. The Dahlias should be pleased.

Nell was delighted by the haul of frilly, beautiful, useless things we brought her.
"You see," she said, admiring a silver snuff box. "This way I get what I want, and you get what you want. Here's your payment."

"That's all you found?" Nell was disappointed. "I guess our scouts were wrong about that place. But at least you found a few nice things for us, like this [antique tea set|beautiful glass vase|silk kimono]. Here's your payment."
I kept a straight face as I lied. I wonder if she suspected that we kept the best shinies for ourselves.
Nell still wants us to scavenge luxuries for her.

"The reason we don't see many female soldiers," Nell said, "has nothing to do with upper body strength. Any weakling can pull a trigger. The reason is that young girls only see men in those roles, and grow up thinking it's a man's job."
"Can you imagine how much better defended we'd be if every young woman was as good with a pistol as her male counterpart? So I'm suggestion we try some affirmative action. I'd like to see your soldiers at least half women."
She's really thinking ahead...

"It's a start." Nell sighed. "I just think that we have a chance here, a clean slate, and we don't have to recreate the same tired old gender roles we had before. Why not make women the politicians and programmers, and men can wait tables and take care of children?"
"Or here's an idea: make it all equal, so every little kid can grow up to do and be whatever they want, regardless of their gender? It's a nice dream, isn't it..."

We had a deep discussion about the question of nature vs nurture, and whether gender stereotypes are hurting children so much as giving them a clear simple path to social acceptance and personal identity. Wear pink, play with dolls, done. You belong.
One thing we both agreed on: nobody should be prevented from doing what they want just because of their gender. We decided to leave it at that.
Nell is still concerned about female representation in the troops. She wants to see at least half of our soldiers be women.

[FactionLeader] thinks it's time we swear loyalty to [faction]. I thought [factionHe] meant an alliance of equals, but what [factionHe]'s describing is more like submission to their rule.
This is awkward... some of our people definitely won't like this idea. Does [FactionLeader's] friendship mean this much to us?

[We] got out there and declared ourselves to be loyal servants... um, I mean friends, of [faction].
Some of our people are upset, saying they didn't sign up for this when they joined and certainly wouldn't have agreed to it. But this is how politics go; sometimes you have to kowtow to the big boys whether you like it or not.

I gave it the old "Yea, forsooth" and confused both sides into thinking I was agreeing with them. [Faction] thought I was praising their strength and benevolence, while our people heard it as ironic; actually a hidden statement of defiance against their bullying.
Hurrah for words! Good politicians can make them mean anything.
Are we ready to declare our allegiance to [faction]?
[We] asked [FactionLeader] what they needed, though I could already see it in [factionHis] eyes: they're hungry. [FactionHe] says that 20 days' rations could very well save some lives here.

[FactionHis] eyes lit up and I thought I could see a bit of drool on the side of [factionHis] mouth at the thought of eating a proper meal. I hope they make this food last and don't just pig out on it.
[FactionLeader] agreed that yes, we're probably right, [factionHe] doesn't really need to eat breakfast _every_ day. Maybe just on Sundays and special occasions.
[Faction] are still very hungry. Can we afford to feed them all?

Senator Davis handed [us] some kind of requisition form. "Perfect timing citizen[s], we have an assignment for your engineers."
I cringed at the word "citizen[s]" and the way she called it an "assignment", but obediently read through the form to see what they need.
Ammunition. Fifty packs of it, as quickly as we can produce it in a workshop. Wow... that's quite the requisition.

The senator didn't seem surprised at all that we'd actually delivered such an ungodly number of bullets for pretty much no reward at all. I suppose she thinks we're just doing our "civic duty" to the government.

[We] told the senator she could take half, or she could shove it.
Well... [we] [were] more diplomatic than that. [We] said it'd be better for [CityName] if our soldiers kept the rest and handled zombie defense at our end of town.
She read between the lines. We're being generous as it is, letting her pretend we did this out of civic duty rather than to avoid their bullying.
The senator is still waiting for us to produce ammunition for them.

"I'm assigning you to Street Cleanup at the [square]" the senator told [us]. "We need all the cars towed out of the road there so our military vehicles can get through."
It's true, right now it's hard to get anything bigger than a bicycle through the streets without driving up on the sidewalk. But this is a boring, tedious job. It's insulting that she "assigned" it to us.

The streets around the [square] were a gridlock of bumper to bumper traffic; rusted frames still endlessly waiting for the car ahead to move forward. The failed exodus. Of course none of them would start, even the ones with the keys still in the ignition, so it took us the entire day to push or tow them away.
At least the zed weren't too bad; we took care of the ones who turned up to see what the ruckus was all about. We should include this in our full report to the Government.

Seatbelts save lives. Most of the time. But from the carcasses buckled neatly into their seats all over town, I'm guessing seatbelts don't help when zombies are smashing in through your windshield to eat your face.
Some of the buckled bodies were now undead, but they were so snugly strapped in they could only wave their arms at us pathetically as we towed their cars out of the road. It'll be easier for the Government to get their vehicles through this part of town now.
They'd be better at it (lvl 9 leader)

I started telling one particularly gruesome story of a zombie we ran over while moving all the cars, but Senator Davis wasn't interested.
"Is it in the report?" she asked. "Good. I'm sure one of our clerks will be delighted to read about it."

[We] convinced the senator that one of their tanks could do a much more efficient job of clearing the street. If they can't push it out of the way, they can just flatten it and drive over.
I also hinted that we were not into taking cleanup jobs like this. If she wants to have us as allies, she better not try this again.
Senator Davis is waiting for us to finish clearing cars off the road.

I asked [FactionLeader] if there was anything they need. [FactionHe] said [factionHe]'d kill for [a] {1}; their scavengers just couldn't find one anywhere. Or if we had [a] {2}, they can't get enough of those.
[FactionHe] was grateful we'd had [a] {1} to spare. [FactionHe] joked that we can have it back when [factionHe]'s done with it, or [factionHe] dies, whichever came first.
[FactionHe] was grateful we'd had [a] {2} to spare. [FactionHe] joked that we can have it back when [factionHe]'s done with it, or [factionHe] dies, whichever came first.

O'Grady and I discussed churches. "The glory of the Lord cannot be contained in an apartment building or the back of an 8-12 mart." he said. "Our Father demands a suitably glorious place of worship. A church of soaring spires and inspiring artworks. Or perhaps five. Or ten."

O'Grady was skeptical. "Those aren't non-denominational churches are they? I tell you, the Lord does not share His house with heathens."
[We] assured him that Sundays were strictly for Catholic mass. Well, except this week because the Seventh-day Adventists reserved it for their potluck.
O'Grady shook his head at our religious tolerance, but accepted that we were headed in the right direction at least.

[We] convinced O'Grady that God is in our hearts, so we don't need stone buildings to hold him. Well, not as _many_ stone buildings.
He seemed to respect that.
Father O'Grady still wants us to have 10 churches.

As we spoke, O'Grady lapsed casually into quoting scripture:
"And Peter said to them, 'Repent and be baptized every one of you for the forgiveness of your sins, and you will receive the gift of the Holy Spirit.'"
"Acts 2:38" he said. "Do you know what it means?"
Apparently it means we need more converts. He thinks at least half our people should be devout churchgoers.
Father O'Grady nodded with respect at this news. He left [us] with a warning: "Whoever believes and is baptized will be saved, but whoever does not believe will be condemned."

[We] had a philosophical debate with O'Grady so intense that it made him even doubt his own faith. I kind of hated to do it to the guy, but he's wrong to believe so blindly without questioning some of the stuff written in that book of his. And he's double wrong to preach it to others instead of letting them come to their own conclusions.
In the end he admitted that at least we did know a lot about religion, and he respects that.

Father O'Grady still thinks at least half our survivors should be devout. We can't force them to convert, but I suppose we could encourage it by assigning them to missions with devout people. Assigning preachers to our churches should help too.

[FactionLeader] is looking for a show of loyalty. In public, in front of the rest of the [factionNoThe], [factionHe] wants a simple gesture of fidelity from our faction to theirs. Not a big deal, [factionHe] insists, [factionHe] just wants to see [us] do it.

[FactionHe] didn't literally have a ring. [We] just shook hands where everyone could see us and I spoke loudly about [how organized their defenses were|how lovely their clean streets were|their bountiful food supply].

Eww, no, the ring was just a metaphor. What I actually did was give a rousing speech about the partnership between us and [faction]. I extolled the virtues of our benevolent friend [FactionLeader].
I went overboard and some of it might have been made up, but [FactionLeader] was moved by it.
[FactionLeader's] waiting to see our gesture of fidelity.

"It's all about the juice, the precious juice, you know?" Dara said. "Gasoline or oil, yeah, they're useful, but I mean electricity, voltage, alternating current!"
"There's no civilization without electricity, okay? So get some."
We have a working power plant
"Yeah," Dara said, "we're on generators too. They're okay, but way inefficient. We spend half our time just scavenging fuel for the things."

Dara was surprised. "Right on? You got that old plant running again? Wow, your fort is totally baller now! Hey listen... maybe we can get our two systems hooked up together, you know, in case one goes down."
Dara still thinks we need electricity.

Dara was in a philosophical mood. "Knowledge is more than power. Knowledge brings order to the chaos, man. Knowledge is life."
She said she thinks we should be valuing engineering and technology higher than anything else. She'd like to see more trained engineers in our fort.

"Yeah, that's a start." Dara nodded. "But we can't forget what the point of all this rebuilding is. We don't just want to survive, we want to achieve. Reach back up to the stars, take our place among them. Keep evolving our minds, you know? That kind of thing."
"Epic! That's what I'm talking about! Wizards of the modern age, wielding science like magic. We've got to preserve technology man, for the future."
Dara still wants us to have more engineers.

"We need your help to do this raid." Dara said. "Not, like, robbing some other faction. No, like a _dungeon_ raid. It's too high-level for us to handle on our own, so we're LFG on this one."
I was still confused, so she explained: we'll meet their people at [a] [square] and attack the zed there together. We should return after we've "killed the boss and collected the loot."

[We] met up with some of the 1337cREw at the [square]. Not Dara though... guess she had guild business to attend to.
The guys who did show were nervous and ill equipped, so it looks like [we're] going to be leading this one.
So... there's a bunch of zombies up ahead. How do we deal with them?

We pewpewed [our] way to victory from a safe distance. The 1337cREw guys mostly stood behind [us] and let [us] use up all [our] ammo. Typical.
At least we found some good stuff here. Better bring it back to the 1337cREw fort so we can divide it up properly.

Melee is dangerous. [We] screwed up, or to be precise one of the 1337cREw newbs screwed up and I got tackled. No bites, thank the stars, but they had to take me out on a stretcher.
At least we cleared that place out and found some nice loot. We should head back to the 1337cREw next to divvy it up.

Zed don't always die right away when you stab them in the head. Sometimes they lose control of the left side of their body, but not the right, or they go blind or start walking in circles. They're still dangerous, so you've got to stab, and retreat. Stab, and retreat. [We] got pretty good at it.
The 1337cREw guys were predictably useless, but at least they stayed out of [our] way and they helped carry the loot we scavenged. We should head back to their fort to divide it up.

One of the 1337cREw newbs got a little scorched when she got too close to our homemade firebombs. She's pretty angry, mostly because I won't stop laughing at her missing eyebrows.
We roasted all the zed. The smell was... well I don't think I'll want to eat again for awhile. But we killed them all, and scavenged everything we could find.
We should head back to Dara to divvy up the loot.

"Wicked run guys, good haul too." Dara pawed through the goods and gave us our share. "Those gankers never stood a chance against your might, etcetera etcetera. Now go fetch me fifteen goblin scalps."
I gave her a blank look and she laughed. "Just joshing. I'm the quest giver, right? So come back next week for a new quest."

[We] told Dara we'd done all the work ourselves, so we were keeping all the loot for ourselves.
"Awww." she complained. "You totally ninja'd the loot! No fair!"
"Did you finish that raid yet? Did the monsters drop any legendary loot?"

"We were prepping for the apocalypse long before it happened, you know." said Ludd. "Had nearly 20 acres of farms all self-sufficient, and five year's supply of preserves in our cellars. Such a shame those raiders made off with most of it in the first year."
He'd like to see us build enough farms to survive on like they do, without needing to scavenge for packaged food in the city.

Ludd was mightily impressed by our farms. He gave us some secret fertilizer to try out on them.
"Night soil"... some kind of dirt you have to collect at night or something? It sure stinks, but it works.

Ludd was skeptical. "You aren't using GM frankenfoods over there, are you? Pesticides? Then how do you grow so much in so little space?"
[We] told him the numbers don't lie... our fields are just more productive than theirs. He was impressed.
"Try some of this" he said, and sent [us] home with a heaping wheelbarrow of foul-smelling dirt. "Best all-natural fertilizer you can get. From me to you."
Ludd still wants us to build enough farms to be self-sufficient.

"If we don't do something about this rampant technology," Ludd told [us] bitterly, "soon we'll be destroying the world all over again."
"Light pollution from searchlights, electric fences harming local wildlife. I thought we were past all this! The only thing to do is destroy all places of research. No more labs!"

Ludd was happy to hear this. "Damn straight! Teach your engineers to scavenge, I'm sure they'll make great farmers. Everyone can farm, it's in our bones. Subsistence living is how society was meant to be."

[We] debated with Ludd for hours on what turned out to be his favorite topic: the dangers of technology.
It eventually came down to [our] belief that theories should be tested, and his belief that science "didn't have all the answers" so it couldn't possibly disprove Ludd's theories.
We agreed to disagree. At least we both walked away from it without fighting.
The Luddies still want us to destroy all our labs.

[Faction] need 10 loads of building materials. [FactionLeader] says they're to [shore up a weak wall|put a new roof on one of their houses|build a lookout tower on their eastern wall] but I don't think you'd even need half that many materials for such a project.
Not sure if [factionHe]'s lying, or their builders are just that inefficient...

[FactionHe] seemed surprised that we actually gave them the full amount. "Um.. thank you." [factionHe] said. "We needed these quite badly."
The way [factionHe] almost laughed when [factionHe] said that, I have to wonder if they're just going to trade these to Gustav for smokes and brandy.

[FactionHe] admitted we were right, that 5 loads should be enough for their needs right now. [FactionHe] said they could always use more though, so if we ever have extra materials in the future, their traders will give us a good deal for them.
[Faction] still want 10 materials for their construction project.

Tiff took [us] up on one of their guard platforms, then laid down to look a the sky. "You know what's just the best?" she sighed. "Bath salts."
"I mean, I wouldn't want to pick up a gun without some. Normally I can't aim for crap, but on salts I'm a crack shot... And they make you feel so _good_."
She wants us to use more bath salts. Of course, she's got an interest in it since we buy the stuff from her.
"Wow? Half?" Tiff was surprised. "You guys must be our best customers. Why don't we give you a discount? Let's make it half price."

"Listen, you're preaching to the wrong girl here. I mean, you're entitled to your opinion and I thank you for being honest and all, but I'm entitled to tell you you're wrong about these bath salts. They are _the best_."
"Now get out of here narc, you're harshing my buzz, as they say."
Tiff still thinks we need to use more bath salts.

"I've told you a dozen times," Tiff said, "I don't lead the Pharmacists or control them. We're an organization of free people who answer to no one. I speak for us because I'm the only one who can stand this boring political schmoozing."
"You know what, I'd like to see your people try the same. For one day, how about casting off your opressive government and governing yourselves for a change?" she started to chant: "Anarchy! Anarchy!"

"Yay! Smash things! Nobody work!"
What, what? This wasn't what [we]'d intended, but as soon as we told our people we'd be anarchists for one day, they all stopped working.
I guess proper anarchy is more complicated than just having no government. How did Tiff convince [us] this was a good idea?

"Ah alright you wimp[s], you're no fun." Tiff pouted. "Though honestly your people probably couldn't handle it."
Here comes a lecture...
"Stable anarchism can't just happen overnight." she said. "People who are used to being led don't know what to do once the boss is gone... they gotta realize that being free means taking responsibility into your own hands. You gotta _become_ the boss. It's not as easy as it seems."
She seemed satisfied that [we] at least listened to her.
Tiff is still waiting on us to try out anarchy.

Farmer Bucket was in one of his weird giggly moods. "Hee hee hee! It's nearin' time ta move them piglets ta the new barn. Y'all should see this year's brood! Hee hee."
"But them pigs is ornery this season and we're shorthanded ta deal with 'em. Hee hee! Do y'all have any warm bodies y'all can spare?"
He says anybody will do and we can come back with them tomorrow. Their fort is safe with plenty of food, but we probably won't see our survivor again on account of the long hours they work.

[Name] didn't want to go, but agreed to since it would help the rest of us. I'm sure [he]'ll adjust to life there just fine. Those pig farmers are always laughing, and people with a good sense of humor like that can't be too bad to live with.
Farmer Bucket gave us some pork chops to say thanks. He winked and said they might taste a little gamey on account of the natural diet they're fed.

[Name2] didn't want to go, but agreed to since it would help the rest of us. I'm sure [he2]'ll adjust to life there just fine. Those pig farmers are always laughing, and people with a good sense of humor like that can't be too bad to live with.
Farmer Bucket gave us some pork chops to say thanks. He winked and said they might taste a little gamey on account of the natural diet they're fed.
The Pig Farmers are still hoping one of our survivors wants to join them. Whoever goes, it will be for good.

"Sales is slow as molasses this month." Farmer Bucket told [us]. "Guess I'm not cut out ta be a businessman like that Gustav."
He giggled at the thought. "Hah! Imagine me out there, going from town ta town... I got the beard for it I s'pose, but no [sir], I'd prefer ta stay here at my farm thank you very much."
I guess that means it's up to us to come to them. Farmer Bucket wants us to buy pork from them more regularly.
We have enough (30 food, lvl 5 leader)
"That's right [sonny], eat a good helpin' of meat with every meal to keep them muscles growin'. Ain't nothing better for a strong body than a piece o' pork flesh."

"I'll bet y'all are some of them vegetarian types... " Bucket giggled. "You don't know what you're missing! Once you taste some you ain't never goin' back to eatin' taters!"
[We] told him maybe next time, but we have plenty of food for now.
Farmer Bucket still wants us to buy food from their traders.

[FactionLeader] wanted to talk about our policy on {1}. [FactionHe]'s concerned that we haven't considered the social ramifications of the way we're headed with it. In short, [factionHe] thinks we should change it to "{2}".
I'm not sure it's really any of [faction's] business...

[FactionLeader] is pretty angry with us. Some time ago we promised we'd change our policy on {1} to "{2}", but we've flip-flopped since then. [FactionHe] thinks we were lying about changing it before and is very disappointed in us.

[FactionLeader] pretended that this had nothing to do with [factionHim]... the only reason [factionHe] wanted us to change our policy was because it would be better for us.
Yeah, right...
After much convincing, we managed to come to a common ground on the issue of {1}, although I think [Faction] would have preferred if we just jumped through [factionHis] hoops instead.
[FactionLeader] still wants us to set our policy on {1} to "{2}".

[FactionLeader] was in a philosophical mood. We walked around their grounds and discussed why we're rebuilding [CityName], and what the point of it all was. It seems we have differing opinions: our priority is "{2}", whereas [faction's] is "{1}".
[FactionHe] implied that we should change ours... but this is a pretty big deal, it might upset people to make such a fundamental policy change just because some other faction asked us to.

[FactionLeader] is pretty angry with us. Some time ago we promised that our highest priority was changed to {1}, like theirs, but we've flip-flopped since then. [FactionHe] thinks we were lying about changing it before and is very disappointed in us.

Some of our survivors were disappointed when they found out we'd decided to focus on "{1}" just because [faction] asked us to.
It's a shame... I think they would've even agreed with it otherwise. At least [FactionLeader] is happy.

I explained to [FactionLeader] that even if our leaders shared [factionHis] ideals, we can't just shift our community's guiding principle like that. Especially not because some other faction thinks it's a good idea.
[FactionHe] just laughed and said it's too bad our leaders are at the mercy of democracy. I'm not sure if [factionHe] was kidding...
[FactionLeader] wants to know if we've decided to change our highest priority, so that our policy matches theirs: {1}.

[Faction] are having a recruitment drive. Specifically, they're looking for {1}s to join them, and will treat them very well if they do. I can think of a few of our survivors who wouldn't mind joining [faction], or we could bring someone else. The question is, can we live without them if they leave?
Should we send someone to permanently live with [faction]? They'll be gone forever...

To be honest, I'm not sure I'll miss [Name] all that much. I went to visit and make sure [he] was doing okay, and [he] kept saying how much better everything is in [faction's] fort. Way to rub it in...

To be honest, I'm not sure I'll miss [Name2] all that much. I went to visit and make sure [he2] was doing okay, and [he2] kept saying how much better everything is in [faction's] fort. Way to rub it in...
They still want to recruit {1}s. Should we send someone to permanently live with [faction]?
[FactionLeader] seemed disappointed that we couldn't fulfill their request. [FactionHe]'ll probably punish us by having some new, even worse thing for us to do next week.

I think [FactionLeader's] giving [us] the silent treatment like some kind of child. When I said we couldn't do it, [factionHe] just shrugged and went back to what [factionHe]'d been doing.
I said something like "So... see you next week?" but [factionHe] acted like I wasn't even there.

[FactionLeader] was clearly frustrated by our refusal to help them. I tried to explain that we would if we had the resources, but [factionHe] didn't seem to believe me. I suppose we can come back next week and hope [factionHe] feels like talking to us again then.

A [factionAdjective] scout rushed in while we were speaking. In a hurried whisper, he reported that "it's happened again", this time at the [square].
[FactionLeader] sent him away. [FactionHe] explained that one of their scouts keeps getting into trouble and seems to be trapped at the [square].
[FactionHe] thinks this is an opportunity to prove ourselves and earn a reward. If we can rescue this guy, [faction] will give us 5 materials.

It's worse than we'd expected... [faction's] missing scout has been captured by bandits. [We] listened in for long enough to learn they're holding him for ransom, and expect [faction] will pay "like they always do".
One of the bandits is teasing their prisoner with a gigantic knife, saying he's going to slice off a finger to send with the ransom note this time.

[Our] attack did not go well. That crazy guy with the knife was faster than he looked. Sliced a chunk out of my thigh and damn near hit an artery.
At least [we] distracted them for long enough that the prisoner could escape. They ran off after him; I guess compared to that ransom, they didn't even think [we] [were] worth finishing off.
I guess we should check back with [faction] and see if the guy got away or not.

[We] rocked in there and [shot] the guy with the knife before the others could even reach for their weapons. The rest of the fight went just as well and [we] walked out of there without a scratch on [us].
The [factionAdjective] guy [we] rescued didn't know why this kept happening to him... but he was glad he still had all his fingers.

The bandits walked off chuckling and pawing through the sacks of food [we] gave them. Damn opportunists, probably not the last we'll see of them.
The prisoner couldn't explain why he keeps getting into trouble like this. He said he'd meet us back at the [factionAdjective] base.
[FactionLeader] was glad to see their missing scout back home again. [FactionHe] apologized for any trouble the guy had caused, and gave us the materials [factionHe]'d promised.

I convinced [FactionLeader] that if the guy was such a nuisance that they wouldn't even try to save him themselves, we'd take him off their hands.
[FactionHe] eventually agreed. [FactionHe] said the guy, [FormalName], was a klutz and always getting into trouble. Hopefully [he]'ll be safe with us.
[Faction] are still waiting for their missing man to return...

Malik took me to their training hall to watch men and women sparring and balancing in graceful crane stances. He gave a few pointers, then spoke to [us]:
"Every man, woman and child in our dojo knows how to fight. Each one is a soldier. Each can defend themselves if called to do so. I would like to see your people trained like this."
I guess he's saying all our people should have at least a little skill in defense.
All our survivors have lvl 1 defense
Malik nodded solemnly. "Your people have an impressive devotion to the art of self-defense. I respect this."

[We] argued that it is more efficient to specialize. An engineer will be better at their job if they can focus on it without having to learn self-defense too.
Malik thought perhaps [we] [were] right, so long as we could guarantee there will always be a professional soldier around to protect that engineer.
We have plenty of those, so we should be alright.
Malik still wants all our people to have at least a little skill in defense.
"I am looking for a challenge." Malik told [us]. "A good fight. One-on-one, no weapons, no stakes but our pride. I want to meet your best warrior. If you are not [him], please bring them to me."

Malik flipped [Name] onto [his] back so many times I think [he] forgot which way was up. But [he] was back up on [his] feet again every time, dodging and kicking in clumsy pseudo-karate style.
Malik won of course, but seemed happy that [Name] made him sweat for it. I think [Name] learned something too.

We knew this was going to be a good fight when [Name] kicked the glasses off Malik's face and bloodied his lip.
Malik changed to a defensive stance after that, but it was clear [Name] had the advantage. After twenty minutes, Malik stepped out of the ring and bowed deeply, smiling through his bloody lip and black eye.
He gave [Name] a pair of nunchuks to thank [him] for the challenge. I think [Name] learned something too.
Malik is waiting for our best warrior to challenge him to a match.

"Howdy friend[s]!" Jesse smiled. "Nice to see a pinkskin that ain't actively trying to put one of us in the ground."
We spoke of their recent troubles with raiders and other groups. Sounds like most of them think of the Rotten as zombies... zombies with supplies they can steal.
Jesse asked if we could teach them to build better walls.
"Thankee kindly my friend[s]." Jesse doffed his hat at [us]. These tips'll do the trick.
"Hmm..." Jesse contemplated the blueprints [we]'d handed him. "We're gonna need electricity for this, but looks like it'll be worth it."
Jesse's still keen to improve their walls with some new technology. "No offence," he told us, "But your kind ain't always kind to our kind."

"I'm the oldest kid here by a mile," Rufus confided, "but we have a rule. Kids have to leave on their 14th birthday. Before we had that rule there was a lot of trouble."
He introduced me to a boy whose 14th birthday was coming up. The kid still looked so childish, cradling a baby and shyly avoiding my eyes. It's hard to imagine he'll be a man soon.

Young [FormalName] is a bit wild from [his] time with St Michaels, but [he]'ll figure things out.
[He]'ll have to soon, because before long [he]'ll be old enough for the same duties as the rest of us.

Rufus didn't want to part with one year old [Name2], but I eventually convinced him the baby'd be better off in our care
The boy, [FormalName], is very protective of [his] little [brother] [Name2]. I doubt they're physically related, but it's a very sweet relationship. Neither has any ill effects from all those food fights and nonsense at St Michael's.

The young teen I met earlier was playing peekabo with the baby this time... I really wonder how these kids manage to raise babies here at all. They might both be better off with us, if we have room for them.
"Why are adults all such bummers?" Rufus asked [us]. "You guys are like, never happy. Cheer up! I want to see you having fun over there!"

"Then it's time for a _water fight_!" Rufus yelled and rolled behind a table, spraying [us] from a water gun he'd had behind his back.
I ducked for cover, then spotted a pile of water balloons in the corner. Grenades! I tossed a book at Rufus to distract him, then dove for the balloons.
We were all thoroughly soaked and smiling by the time we declared a truce. Nobody wins in war. Everybody wins in a water fight.

I explained to Rufus that this is totally normal. Adults aren't supposed to be happy. We know all about the world and all the good reasons there are to be sad. I gave him a few examples from my own experiences.
This really bummed Rufus out. He said he respects [us] for being honest with him though.
Rufus still thinks we're downers and wants to see us cheer up.

"Bwah!" Rufus punched a wall. "I _hate_ schools. I hate everything _about_ this place!"
I tried to ask what was wrong, maybe he's just cranky because he needs a nap? But he rounded on me. "I hope that's a joke [mister], cuz this isn't funny. Schools are prisons for children. You might not remember cuz you're like a million years old now, but they're bad places. Burn them all down."

"Hahaha yeah, you know it!" Rufus kicked over a desk in triumph. "Screw school! Schools were just a way for parents to avoid taking real care of their kids."
"Also," he added, "screw parents."

I asked him why they all live in a school if he hates them so much.
"Well," he said, "the gym is great, and the shop and the science rooms have some pretty cool stuff in them I guess. Also it's crazy defensible cuz they totally built it like a prison."
I got him to admit that schools aren't all bad, so long as you have the right teachers.
Rufus still wants us to "burn down all the schools". Except the one he lives in, I guess.
[FactionLeader] had a gift for us today. {1}. I asked what it was for, but [factionHe] just said they had too much and we could put it to good use.
I thanked [factionHim] for it. I have a feeling there's more to this than [factionHe]'s letting on. Maybe [faction] are afraid we might attack them if they don't stay on our good side.

I pressured [factionHim] into doubling the amount, subtly implying that we could just come take it ourselves if [faction] didn't want to give it to us.
[FactionHe]'s obviously lost a little respect for us because of it, but hey, that extra {1} was worth it.
[FactionLeader] again offered us {1}. [FactionHe] wasn't sure why we didn't just take it before...

We got to discussing defenses, and I mentioned our engineers have plans for a nice tower that can be added to almost any structure. [FactionLeader] asked if we could build one at their [square].
It would really improve their defenses and general strength in combat... assuming that's something we want.

[We] upgraded [faction's] defenses with a new {1}, just like they asked. I'm not sure I agree with this, but [we] worked all day in the hot sun while [faction] stood around and watched us. Hopefully this is worth it...
[We] took [FactionLeader] up to see the new tower. From up there, you could see anything coming from four or five blocks away. [FactionHe] was impressed by our sturdy craftsmanship.
All of [faction] were impressed by the new tower. It's a big improvement to their defenses.
[FactionLeader] wants to know if we finished that tower yet.

[FactionLeader] wants to set up traps to catch zombies before they get too close to their fort. [FactionHe]'s heard we know how to build effective ones, and wants us to make some for them.
[FactionHe] asked us to bring 5 traps for them to install.
[FactionLeader] must think we're real pushovers, giving them whatever they ask for like this and making them stronger. But we're doing it for us in the long run.

I tactfully explained that they could use one trap as a prototype to make their own, praising the intelligence of their engineers and implying they'd do a better job than ours anyway. [FactionHe] seemed pleased.
[Faction] still want 5 zombie traps from us.

We got to chatting about {1}. To say [faction] don't like them very much is a bit of an understatement. The two groups are in a kind of cold war, sending anonymous raiders to steal each other's supplies, and sabotaging their operations in the city.
[FactionLeader] has had enough, and thinks it's time to drive them out of [CityName]. [FactionLeader] wants us to go to war with {1}.

[FactionLeader] thought this was fantastic news; [factionHe] bubbled over like a popped bottle of champagne, pulling me to a map of the city so we could synchronize our military strategy and hit them where it hurts the most.
[FactionLeader] thanked us for removing {1} from [CityName]. I'm not sure what [factionHe] ever had against them, but [factionHe]'s sure glad they're gone.

We talked for a long time, trying to figure out why exactly [faction] and {1} can't get along in the same city. I felt like a psychiatrist, trying to find the root of the problem that must be deeper than a simple squabble over territory or resources.
In the end I convinced [factionHim] to give peace with {1} a chance.
[FactionLeader] still wants us to go to war with {1}.

I asked [FactionLeader] if there was anything we could do for them. [FactionHe] told me they have a bit of a zombie problem in a [square] beside one of their walls. If we could solve it for them, [faction] would be most grateful. I'm not sure they care _how_ we do it, so long as those zed are killed.
We finished those zed off just like the good little [factionAdjective] lackeys we are. Better head back to meet with [FactionLeader] and give [factionHim] the report.

[FactionHe] was impressed that we'd go out of our way to help them like that.
I told [factionHim] that the zombies endanger us all, no matter whose walls they're banging at.

[We] asked [factionHim] why we'd send our soldiers halfway across the city when [faction] could practically shoot the damn things from their own walls.
[FactionHe] seemed a little shamed by this but agreed that of course it made sense. [We] gave them some ammo so they could kill them safely from a distance.
[FactionLeader] asked if we'd managed to kill those zed in the block beside their fort.

We thwarted a couple thugs today who tried to grab [FormalName] while [he] was out [missioning]. At least, I think they were trying to hurt [him].
Things happened so fast, I just reacted as we'd agreed in our policy: don't trust anyone until they prove they can be trusted. These guys had guns, and their hands on [Name]. Whatever their intentions, they're dead now.

Zombies aren't the only threat in this lawless world. A group of frighteningly armed men kidnapped [FormalName] while [he] was out [missioning]. They seemed trustworthy at first, then snatched [him] so fast, we didn't know what had happened. Now they're demanding ransom and threatening to sell [Name] as a slave if we don't pay.
Honestly, I think these slavers are going to get more than they bargained for if they try to hold onto [Name], but we could buy [him] back for 20 food.

[FormalName] never should have trusted those travelers when they invited [him] over to their camp to play cards. Turns out they're some kind of slave traders and they've taken [Name] hostage. Maybe [he] got a bit too nosy, or maybe they'd planned to kidnap [him] all along, we're not sure.
They're offering to return [him] in exchange for 20 food. If we don't pay up, according to these men this may be the last we'll ever see of our friend.

We handed over the food and got [Name] back. [He]'s exhausted, and ready to murder [his] former captors given half the chance, but otherwise none the worse for wear.
I feel bad having given in to these terrible people. I'm not sure whether to take their threats of "selling" [Name] seriously. Are there really people out there who _own slaves_? If so, it may be worse out there than I could have possibly imagined.

Our attack went terribly wrong. The slavers slit [Name's] throat before we could even get close to [him] and, to add injury to insult, put a bullet in [Name2's] knee as they left.
No human should never be the property of another, not ever, ever again. Slavery is one horror that I'm willing to fight to the death to oppose. I just hope [FormalName] would have agreed.

I stalled, pretending to negotiate the price while the others snuck into position. We laid into the slavers mercilessly, cutting them down where they stood. After we put a couple in the ground, the rest ran off.
[Name] was grateful for being saved, but assured us [he] could have taken them all with one hand tied behind [his] back. I admire [his] spirit, but I'm not so sure it would have ended well if we hadn't stood up and fought back.

It hurt to say goodbye to [Name] but we didn't have the food or the manpower to get [him] out of there. Perhaps [he]'ll find a way to escape on [his] own, but I don't expect to see [him] again either way.
I wonder if we should adjust our policy on trusting strangers... if there are others out there like these slave traders, maybe we should just shoot first and ask questions later.

Nell McClung was in a good mood when I met with her today, humming while she came down the stairs to greet me. We spoke in the expansive, blindingly white foyer of the mansion that served as the Dahlias HQ. I guess everyone could live in a place like this if we wanted to now, but who has the energy to clean this thing?
Ask them to attack Last Judgment

She smiled wide when I suggested we team up against the Last Judgment Gang. "Yes," she agreed, "It's time we finally dealt with that _element_."
We moved to the living room and unfolded a map of [CityName] onto the coffee table. She suggested an aggressive simultaneous attack against as many points as possible. When I suggested she'd be spreading her forces too thin, she laughed.
"You haven't seen my girls at work. Just make sure you attack while the Last Judgment leaders are still away, and we'll be there."

I complimented Ms. McClung on the decor. She replied that white is a wonderful color, because you can just bleach the blood right out of it so easily. We made somewhat awkward small talk for a few minutes after that.

Father O'Grady was away as promised when we attacked their fort. It seems he'd taken their best soldiers with him, or at least their best guns. The kids left behind to guard the place had nothing but pistols and knives to defend with.
When it was clear they were losing, the last defenders jumped on their motorcycles and took off.
Mason and Erica cheered and high-fived at this.

The Dahlias had nearly finished the job by the time we even got there. I guess they started early to make sure they got the glory. And/or the territory.
Father O'Grady was away as promised and the few guards left at home were badly armed. When it was clear they were losing, the last defenders jumped on their motorcycles and took off.
Mason and Erica cheered and high-fived at this.

"Hah, no, we're not a 'couple'." Mason almost blushed. "We're a team, the two of us. I go where she goes. But I'm not really into girls like that, you know?"
They both seemed more interested in joining the Dahlias after watching them kick ass all day. "No offence," said Mason, "But they just really know what they're doing over there."
Looks like the Dahlias got the territory _and_ the spoils, but at least they've agreed to ally with us.
Last Judgment destroyed, alliance with Dahlias

Hah, no, we're not a 'couple'." Mason almost blushed. "We're a team, the two of us. I go where she goes. But I'm not really into girls like that, you know?"
They both seemed interested in joining the Dahlias after watching them kick ass all day. "No offence," said Mason, "But they just really know what they're doing over there."
Looks like the Dahlias got the territory _and_ the spoils, but at least they've agreed to ally with us.
Last Judgment destroyed, alliance with Dahlias

"Hah, no, we're not a 'couple'." Mason almost blushed. "We're a team, the two of us. I go where she goes. But I'm not really into girls like that, you know?"
They both agreed to join us. I don't know if we'll hear from Father O'Grady again after such a massive defeat, but the rest of the Last Judgment have vacated and their fort is now ours.

"Hah, no, we're not a 'couple'." Mason almost blushed. "We're a team, the two of us. I go where she goes. But I'm not really into girls like that, you know?"
The two seemed a little sad that we didn't ask them to join us, but we've got enough problems without these two getting into trouble at every turn. They salvaged a couple bikes from the Last Judgment fort and rode off into the sunset together.

I bumped into Mason Moon at the Last Judgment fort. He was hard to miss, since he was in the middle of a fistfight with two other guys. I think they were his friends from earlier - Bebop and Rocksteady? Something like that.

"It's my fault," the woman explained. "Mason's having trouble fitting in around here, so I told him the next time they pick on him to start a fight. It usually works for me."
The girl's name was Erica, another young initiate to the Last Judgment Gang. She and Mason had joined together a little over six months ago, but neither was making any friends.
"The women aren't allowed to ride bikes, " Erica complained, "they make us cook and clean the chapel all day. And I hate Bible study."

Mason poked his finger at me. "Because the Last Judgment Gang are way badder asses than _your_ group. We've got the power of righteousness on our side." Erica nodded her agreement. "Plus, Father O'Grady saved our lives when he found us." she said more quietly.
Seems like there's no getting through to these two.
Pull the other gang members off him

I stepped in and accidentally joined the fray. I pinned one guy's arms behind him, then the other one kicked me in the back and knocked us both over. I stood up just in time to get punched right in the nose, which sent me sprawling. When my eyes could focus again I looked up to see who'd done it and was surprised to find a smallish young woman offering to help me up.
"Sorry, " she said, "I though you were another one of Mason's asshat friends."

Only Mason looked over at me, successfully distracted just long enough to get punched in the face. Oops.
Then this smallish young woman came storming out of the gathering crowd. "Enough you idiots!" she shouted, brandishing a knife in their faces. "Back off, or I'll cut your ugly mugs up so bad they'll think you're a zombie."
Remarkably they did walk away, eyeing her angrily.

Mason seemed to be holding his own, moving around between lunges so that neither of them could get behind him. A crowd gathered, then suddenly this smallish young woman came storming into the fray. "Enough you idiots!" she shouted, brandishing a knife in their faces. "Back off, or I'll cut your ugly mugs up so bad they'll think you're a zombie."
Remarkably they did walk away, eyeing her angrily.

As Gustav and I shared a couple warm non-alcoholic beers, he mentioned some young bikers causing trouble in [CityName].
Sounds like Mason Moon and his Last Judgment friends have taken to dangerous stunts, herding zed around the city with their motorcycles. _"Foolish cheeldren,"_ Gustav commented, _"Dey will be killed."_
I'm not fond of this kid, but Diane asked me to look after her son when she died. They were last seen heading to an old hospital swarming with undead. Might send someone to check up on them.

[We] thought [we] [were] too late when [we] saw their bikes lying abandoned on the pavement, but [we] soon heard growls and gunfire coming from inside the hospital.
Carefully following the noise without making any more, [we] found Mason's crew barricaded in an operating room on the third floor. A dozen or more zed clawed at the doors in a frenzied hunger for flesh.
[We] need a plan to give the Judgment boys a chance to escape.

Mason grinned at [us], exhilarated by the thrill of escape. He thanked [us] for [our] help, shaking my hand and hugging me, until one of his Last Judgment friends stepped between us and shoved Mason away. "What the _hell_ Mason. You know we didn't need their help. God woulda provided, man. You know that."
"Uh... yeah." Mason straightened up, but he didn't sound so sure. As we parted ways, he said we should come visit him at the Last Judgment fort sometime.

[We] charged into the pack of zed took down a couple of them quickly, but as the fight dragged on more undead began to shamble out of the waiting rooms and offices attracted by the noise.
[We] might have been totally overrun if Mason and his boys hadn't joined the fight. With their help [we] [were] able to hold zed back long enough to make [our] way downstairs and out of the hospital.

I charged into the horde, taking out four before they even reacted. As the dead whirled [we] fell upon them and soon the hallway was awash in putrefied blood.
As [we] led the Last Judgment crew back to their bikes, Mason seemed impressed by the trail of gore [we] left behind us.
Try to lure the zed away

Getting the zed's attention was easy. Losing it was a lot harder. [We]'d been sprinting through the hallways chased by the pack of ravenous undead for fifteen minutes when I heard a cracking noise and the hallway gave way beneath my feet.
I lay painfully on my back in the mess for a minute before Mason's hand grabbed me and pulled me out of the rubble. Together we ran from the hospital as fast as my crippled spine allowed.

All it took was a cry and a few jumping jacks and soon enough [we] [were] running as fast as [we] could through the hallways of the hospital, a pack of ravenous undead at [our] heels.
I noticed a place where the roof leaked and the floor under it was sagging. I leapt over the patch, and second later the ground gave way under the zombies behind me. [We] left them lying in a pile of rubble one floor down and made our way outside. Mason was waiting for [us].

As [we] hunted in the side rooms fruitlessly for anything to use I tripped and knocked over an IV stand into a nearby glass cabinet. Oops.
The chase that followed would have been perfect set to some Benny Hill music as we darted from room to room ahead of the zombies. Eventually we lost them and made our way out of the hospital to find Mason and his crew waiting for us, smirks on their faces.

Hunting through a storeroom I found several compressed oxygen tanks. [We] lined them up at the end of the hallway like a firing squad, then picked up a brick and began to knock the tops off.
The canisters sped down the hallway, bouncing off floors, walls and zed, leaving a trail of broken bodies in their wake. [We] finished off the remaining undead and cleared Mason and his crew a path out of the hospital.

Some Last Judgment bikers just pulled up, their bikes airbrushed with elaborate crosses and scantily clad angels. One of them, a kid maybe 19 or 20 years old named Mason, came to ask about a woman named Diane Moon.
Yes, _that_ Diane Moon. The woman who saved my life and gave it a purpose. The woman whose death I'm responsible for. She was Mason's mother.
I pulled Mason aside before anyone else could talk to him, but I couldn't bring myself to admit the truth...

The other Judgment boys were causing trouble already. They'd cornered [Name] and were trying to get [him] to give up [his] jacket, saying it was "way too nice for such a scrawny little rat".
A crowd was gathering and both sides were starting to reach for their weapons. Mason eyed his fellow gang members worryingly but didn't try to break things up.
The only way we're going to avoid bloodshed here is if I give him a little nudge.

Mason turned on me angrily, and for a second it looked like I'd just made things worse. Then he yelled at his gang mates: "Diggs! Gnasher! Hey guys, leave [him] alone. We're still in trouble with Father O'Grady from the last time."
As he got on his bike, Mason looked back at me and nodded. "Thanks for the info about my mom. Just... never try to tell me what to do." He spun out in a wide arc then drove off in a cloud of dust and exhaust fumes.

"Your friends seem nice," I told Mason sarcastically, "real stand-up individuals."
He sighed, then called out: "Diggs! Gnasher! Hey guys, this isn't why we're here! It's time to go anyway."
He apologized as they were leaving, saying the Last Judgment were supposed to be following the Word of God, but sometimes they forget the whole 'Do unto others as you'd have them do unto you' part.
It's good to know at least one of these bikers has a bit of a conscience.
Say she left on a trip

I told him that after she'd helped me out, Diane had left to hunt the region for other survivors. She left well armed and supplied, but I hadn't heard from her in a while.
Mason was frustrated that I couldn't tell him more, but before he could press me on it we were interrupted by sounds of crashing and angry voices.

I told him that after helping us get started she'd joined up with another group of survivors to help them do the same. I wasn't sure where they were now, but she had seemed fine when last I saw her.
Mason was frustrated that I couldn't tell him more, but before he could press me on it we were interrupted by sounds of crashing and angry voices.

I told him I didn't know where she was now. She just vanished late one night months back. There hadn't been any sign of a struggle, but given how bad things were out there we had eventually given up hope of finding her.
Mason was frustrated that I couldn't tell him more, but before he could press me on it we were interrupted by sounds of crashing and angry voices.

I've got to hand it to those Last Judgment, they sure are passionate about what they believe in.
Though I'm not sure it's healthy for a young guy like Mason Moon to get caught up in their world, they could probably teach him something about commitment to a cause.
What I've learned from the Last Judgment is...

It's the law of the gangster: the strong thrive, and the weak don't survive. You can have all the intelligence, honor and wealth in the world, but if you can't defend yourself you'll be left with nothing.
The Last Judgment Gang know that power and aggression are connected. Sometimes you just have to bust caps in a few asses before people take you seriously.
It's an important lesson I'm glad to have learned.

So long as we've got God on our side, we can't lose. All we've got to do is pray harder and longer than the other guys, and we'll win.
And if we don't win, that's because God's got another plan for us. So long as we trust Him, we'll survive.
And if we don't survive, God's got a reason for that too. We aren't seeing the big picture.
Okay, I think I've got this priest thing down. Grab me a pulpit, I'm ready!

I admit the housing market's gone through a little deflation recently. A nice two-bedroom is going for what, a pack of smokes these days?
But Father O'Grady knows the value of territory, and of developing that territory for maximum profit. A park isn't worth much, but if it's got good soil you can convert it to a potato farm. You turn old office buildings into housing, and build lookout towers on tall buildings.
Listen to me, I sound like a regular real estate developer.
Gained the Real Estate Developer perk

That Father O'Grady is so full of crap it's leaking out his pant-legs. Shooting his gun in the air while quoting scripture: what a hypocrite.
And a bully, too. No, I didn't learn anything from those bikers.

I was in one of our storerooms, obsessively counting and recounting of our food stocks as I do sometimes when I can't sleep. I heard a noise and jumped up in time to catch Mason Moon and his friend Erica from the Last Judgment Gang trying to sneak past me.
They swear they didn't steal anything, they were just looking for a place to sleep. Erica got in some trouble with the Last Judgment and they're now on the run.

Mason guffawed at this. "Attack _them_? Have you _seen_ the kind of firepower they're packing? You guys wouldn't stand a chance, it'd be like a lame dog attacking a herd of elephants. And you're the lame dog in this situation in case you didn't know."
I was getting ready to smack him upside the head when he added:
"Although... there _is_ that pilgrimage to Angel Acres they're heading off to for the next week...."

Mason explained that the Last Judgment leaders, along with their highest-ranking and best-armed priests, were heading to a rally in a place called Angel Acres. Father O'Grady was expecting some sort of miracle or message from God to appear there.
If we attack or raid the Last Judgment now, we'll catch them while most of their defenders are away. We could take them down in one swoop. We have one week until they return.

Erica suggested we could try the Dahlias. They hate the Last Judgment Gang anyway. If we let them know that the gang's going to be weaker soon while their leaders are off at that religious rally or whatever, maybe they'll join us in the raid.
"Also the Dahlias are pretty badass," Mason just had to inject, "you guys might learn a thing or two."

Erica and Mason weren't thrilled with our disguise for them: we drove them out of town under dried blood crusted sheets, pretending they were dead bodies being taken for cremation in an outlying graveyard. If the Last Judgment saw us go, they didn't stop us to ask questions.
The two thanked us for our help and wished us the best of luck. I hope they'll be okay out there...

Whatever they did, it was up to Father O'Grady and the Last Judgment Gang to decide their punishment. We dragged them kicking and screaming back to the Last Judgment fort where O'Grady thanked us for our help.
"She nearly killed two of our boys," he said, "and will be dealt with accordingly. The Good Book has it very clear what her punishment should be."
He gave us a small reward and an ominous warning to "stay off the devil's path".
Let them stay and have some food
Turn them in to the Last Judgment Gang

Apparently Erica had made good on her threat to cut the face off any Last Judgment boy who touched her. A couple of them snuck into her room one night; now one is missing an eye and the other a nose.
"They'll kill me if I go back, " she said, "Father O'Grady would never take my side. That's not how things work there. I can't stay in [CityName] with the Last Judgment so close."
Offer to destroy the Last Judgment
Offer to sneak them out of town
Turn them in to the Last Judgment Gang

They were grateful for our hospitality and told their story over dinner. Apparently Erica had made good on her threat to cut the face off any Last Judgment boy who touched her. A couple of them snuck into her room one night; now one is missing an eye and the other a nose.
"They'll kill me if I go back, " she said, "Father O'Grady would never take my side. That's not how things work there. I can't stay in [CityName] with the Last Judgment so close."
Offer to destroy the Last Judgment
Offer to sneak them out of town
Turn them in to the Last Judgment Gang

We failed to attack the Last Judgment Gang while they were away at Angel Acres. Their people have returned and defenses are back to normal again. We missed our chance.
Mason and Erica were disappointed with us and left town. Hopefully they'll be alright out there.
There's an antique biplane on this old farm. I wonder if we could get it flying again.
There's an antique biplane on this old farm.
Everything you could want from guns to decorative candles. Gardening shears big enough to cut a head off? They got 'em.
Everything you could want from guns to decorative candles.
Home sweet home for [arg1] survivors, if they don't mind the 70's decor and avocado-green appliances.
Thick bank walls can hold out zombies for a long time. It adds +[arg1] defense, and +[arg2] to the buildings surrounding it.
Adds +[arg1] defense, and +[arg2] to the buildings surrounding it.
Sometimes you want to go where everybody knows your name. Or settle for any place with alcohol left. Increases happiness.
Subdivisions were named after what was destroyed to make room for them. "Pinewood Grove" has homes for [arg1] survivors.
This is the only place zombies can cross the river. Or humans for that matter.
This is the only place zombies can cross the river. Or humans for that matter.
Cookie cutter houses for [arg1] survivors to live in, assuming you can tell them apart to know which one is yours.
Cookie cutter houses for [arg1] survivors to live in.
Coffee always used to make me jumpy. Now I can get that effect for free just by taking a stroll outside the walls.
Coffee always used to make me jumpy.
Our churches are multi-faith spiritual centers. Now offering over two dozen afterlives to go to when you die. Increases happiness.
Increases happiness especially in devout survivors.
A glorious center of government. Civic pride.
Trashy, revealing clothing for your darling angel teenage daughter.
Trashy, revealing clothing for your darling angel teenage daughter.
A convenient place to buy smokes, junk food, and cola by the bucket. How did we ever survive?
A convenient place to buy smokes, junk food, and cola by the bucket.
Karate skills aren't as useful post-apocalypse as you'd think. Going hand-to-hand with Zed is only for the desperate and mad.
Going hand-to-hand with Zed is only for the desperate and mad.
I wonder if the new [Batman|Star Trek|Wolverine|Bond] movie's out yet? Oh wait... right.
I wonder if the new [Batman|Star Trek|Wolverine|Bond] movie's out yet? Oh wait... right.
Huge farms produce [arg1] food every day, and make an impressive corn maze in the autumn.
Produces [arg1] food every day, and can be actively farmed for more.
Big farms produce [arg1] food every day of healthy crops like chard and turnips. Posting full-time farmers here increases the yield.
Big farms produce [arg1] food every day and can be actively farmed for more.
Farms produce [arg1] food per day and provide valuable vitamins you can't get from canned SPAM. Farming here increases the yield.
Produces [arg1] food per day and can be actively farmed for more.
The deer are thriving in the city's green spaces. They may be faster than the zombies, but they can't outrun a hunter's bullet.
The deer are thriving in the city's green spaces and can be hunted here.
Well I'm not on fire so it must be working.
Well I'm not on fire so it must be working.
This store went out of business long before the zombies came. Replaced by digital markets, just like all the book and music stores.
This store went out of business long before the zombies came.
Cities ran out of fuel during the early days of the big panic, but you can still find cars with gas in their tanks.
Cities ran out of fuel during the early days of the big panic.
The dead never crawled out of their graves like in the movies, but zombies do seem strangely drawn to this horrible place.
Zombies do seem strangely drawn to this horrible place.
I never appreciated how we used to get strawberries all year round from markets like this.
I never appreciated how we used to get strawberries all year round from markets like this.
The beginning of impassible mountains at the edge of the city. There's nothing out here, not even Zed.
The beginning of impassible mountains at the edge of the city.
Survivors heal faster in hospitals, either due to the placebo effect or because once you're in there you'll do anything to get out.
Here our engineers can research everything from zombie behavior to how they used to get the caramel into all those Caramilk bars.
People used to spend hours aimlessly shuffling around these temples of commerce. Nothing's changed, eh?
People used to spend hours aimlessly shuffling around these temples of commerce.
People used to spend hours aimlessly shuffling around these temples of commerce. Nothing's changed, eh?
People used to spend hours aimlessly shuffling around these temples of commerce.
What was that jingle? "You deserve a break today, have some noodles made your way". Makes my mouth water just thinking about it.
Makes my mouth water just thinking about it.
I've heard bed bugs can survive for ages without food but I wonder just how long? [arg1] lucky survivors can live here and find out.
[arg1] lucky survivors can sleep with the bedbugs here.
Zed can't swim, they just sort of bob helplessly in place. They can't dance either, but that doesn't come up as often.
Zed can't swim, they just sort of bob helplessly in place.
We used to spend our lives in these offices, chained to desks, drinking cheap watery coffee to keep from falling into a boredom coma.
We used to spend our lives in these offices.
The pond's covered with scum now that the filtration stopped working, but the fish are fatter and happier than ever.
The fish in the spond are fatter and happier than ever.
The squirrels, pigeons and rabbits have been multiplying like crazy. Good eating if you know how to trap them.
The squirrels, pigeons and rabbits have been multiplying like crazy and can be hunted here.
Other than siphoning fuel from the cars' tanks, this parking lot is as useless as it is ugly.
This parking lot is as useless as it is ugly.
They've got enough used instruments here to start an orchestra. I call trombone!
They've got enough used instruments here to start an orchestra.
Land-o-drugs. Also post office, photo services, consumer electronics, groceries, home & garden and so much more.
Oost office, photos, consumer electronics, groceries, home & garden and more.
I haven't seen a pig in years, but chickens survived and like all birds they're immune to the disease. Produces [arg1] rations per day.
Produces [arg1] rations per day and can be actively farmed for more.
Police stations are the heart of our protection against the outside world. They give +[arg1] defense, and +[arg2] to neighboring buildings.
Increased defense by +[arg1], and gives +[arg2] to neighboring buildings.
A small natural gas plant that might be simple enough for a few engineers to operate.
A tower like this could broadcast our message a hundred miles away. What should it be: easy listening, or golden oldies?
A tower like this could broadcast our message a hundred miles away.
Another one of those hipster eateries whose decor says greasy spoon, and prices say you're better off just eating your money.
Another one of those hipster eateries.
Zombies mill on the banks here but rarely enter the water. We can't reclaim the river but it makes a great natural barrier.
We can't reclaim the river but it makes a great natural barrier.
An ex-building. It probably burned down during the early days of panic and mayhem.
Survivors can train here to increase their skills. It's faster and much safer than the usual way.
Survivors can train here to increase their skills.
Looks like a branch of Incredicorp, that old video game empire. I used to have all their games.
Looks like a branch of Incredicorp, that old video game empire.
If you can stand the darkness, it's actually safer to travel underground these days. Zed don't seem to like it down there.
Zed don't seem to like it down there.
This place looked like a disaster zone even before the disease hit. There's room for [arg1] survivors to live here.
Room for [arg1] survivors to live here.
Adds +50 food storage. You never know what you'll find in these. Boxes of PVC pipes? A room filled with pillows? Expired dog food? Yum!
The city's running water is dependent on this plant. Important for health and happiness.
Impassible deep forest at the edge of the city. Few zombies come through here so we can safely keep our backs to it.
Few zombies come through here so we can safely keep our backs to it.
A place to make things, fix things, and take things apart.

[FormalName] collapsed today of what we think was a brain hemorrhage. It was probably caused by the severe malnutrition we're all suffering from. The good news is, [he] still had a fair bit of fat left on [his] bones. We're so sad to see [him] go, but [his] body will feed us and hopefully we won't succumb to the same fate.

I used to tell [FormalName] [he] was so cute I could just eat [him] up. Now... it looks like that's going to come true. [Name] was killed today while out scrounging for edible weeds outside our walls. If we hadn't been so desperate for food, [he] wouldn't have taken such a risk.
